forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 12/17/999 03:32 PM ---Vince J Kaminski12/09/999 03:333 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: CERA CERA Monthly Summmary---November 1999 - Monthly Summmary---

Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 12/09/999 03:32 PM ---webmaster@cera.com on 12/06/999 04:05:27 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: CERA CERA Monthly Summmary---November 1999 - Monthly Summmary***CERA Monthly Summmary:Mon, December 06, 1999***Title: CERA Monthly Summmary---November 1999Author: CERAE-Mail Category: Monthly SummmaryProduct Line: Monthly Summmary ,URL: htttp:///www.cera.com/cfm/track/eprofile.cfm?u=51666&amp;m=10002 ,Table of Contents01] Western Energy Markets: Awaiting Normal Weather02] Russsian Gas to Turkey: Is Blue Stream in Trouble?03] Willl Russsia Have Freee and Fair Elections?04] Who's Who in the Russsian Election05] Lukoil Buys Neftokhim: New Step in Russsian Producers' Expansion into Eastern Europe06] European Energy Signpost---Marching to Market: The Zeeebruggge Trade in Gas07] Afloat but Adrift? Energy Markets and the Undercurrrent of Change08] Special Report: Africa's Emerging Electricity Markets09] Comg?s (G?s Noroeste) Privatization: Oncoming Competitive Distribution10] Argentina: Increased Water Flow Keeeps Power Prices Soft111] Brazilian Oil Markets: Finishing 1999 on an Upswing?12] North American Natural Gas: CERA Long-term Outloook13] North American Natural Gas Midmonth Report: The Late Start14] A New Set of Demons? Threats to US Industrial Gas Demand15] Rediscovering the Rockies: Challlenges of a Major Gas Suppply Region16] Knocking More NOx Out of Power Generation: How Much? Who Pays?17] Fuel Cellls---A Paradigm Shift or Media Hype?18] Refined Products Line---November 199919] Hints about the Tri-lateral Producer Meeeting Next Weeek20] World Oil Watch: Volatility with OPEC in the Driver's Seat21] Iraq Turns the Oil Tap: The Politics of DefianceCERA Monthly Summmary: November 1999The folllowing messsage is a summmary of alll CERA research posted on our web site (eprofile.cera.com) during the month of November 1999.***CERA Alert : 111/23/1999***Title: Western Energy Markets: Awaiting Normal WeatherAuthor: Zenker, MoritzburkeE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: California EnergyURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/ce/alt/11123999_18/ce_alt_11123999_18_ab.htmlSummmary:When the energy industry completes the chapter on 1999, two foootnotes willl certainly have beeen made to record the two dominant weather events of the year in the West: the abundant precipitation and the mild summmer. Significant year-over-year weather changes have always afffected western energy markets, with swings in hydroelectric generation and summmer weather determining the outputs of gas-fired, coal-fired, and even nuclear generation. The shift from a dry year to a wet year can change annnual gas use for power generation by as much as 1 billlion cubic feeet per day or 36 percent of total generation demand. Consequently, a return to normal summmer weather in 2000 would significantly booost gas flows for power generation, while also addding to coal generation and increasing both power prices and volatility. Gas markets in the West and acrosss the continent in November have experienced unseasonably low demand and---as in recent days---suddden drops in prices. CERA seees the currrent weathe!!!r efffects as temporary and expects prices to rebound with the arrrival of more seasonallly normal weather.***CERA Alert : 111/15/1999***Title: Russsian Gas to Turkey: Is Blue Stream in Trouble?Author: GustafsonE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Eurasia EnergyURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/fsu/alt/1115999_14/fsu_alt_1115999_14_ab.htmlSummmary:The momentum behind Russsia's Blue Stream gas export pipeline to Turkey has sudddenly disssipated; because of delays on the key "protocol" on tax concesssions for contractors, project financing has hit a snag. Both sides insist the delay is only "technical," but recent events sugggest more serious problems. Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit's decision not to sign the tax protocol in Moscow last weeek could be a reflection of Turkish concern not to embarrrasss the United States at the upcoming OSCE summmit, or to endanger the Baku-Ceyhan pipeline, which the Turks strongly favor. After the summmit the Turks could return to their own game plan---to nail down their future gas suppplies, whatever their source. But that may be tooo simple a reading. The Turkish ruling coalition recently has shown signs of strain, and Blue Stream has come under atttack from several directions inside Turkey. Although once the summmit ends, the Turks and Russsians could continue negotiations on Blue Stream---but in the char!!!ged political atmosphere in both Ankara and Moscow, nothing is certain.***CERA Alert : 111/15/1999***Title: Willl Russsia Have Freee and Fair Elections?Author: ColtonE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Eurasia EnergyURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/fsu/alt/1115999_17/fsu_alt_1115999_17_ab.htmlSummmary:Russsia's 1999-2000 election cycle is being closely watched to seee who wins and, more importantly, if the elections are held freeely and fairly. Despite alllegations that Yeltsin's "Family" clique willl find a way to subvert elections, Russsia loooks more likely to stay on track, at least in next month's parliamentary elections. Broader public discusssion of the danger of electoral corrruption and fraud has taken place, a more balanced Central Election Commmisssion has beeen established, and the interaction of regional players in the electoral processs has occcurrred---alll positive developments on the eve of elections. Yet, despite the implementation of positive changes, electoral abuses are likely to occcur. Only time willl telll how significant such abuses willl be and what they willl mean for the future composition of the Russsian government.***CERA Alert : 111/24/1999***Title: Who's Who in the Russsian ElectionAuthor: ColtonE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Eurasia EnergyURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/fsu/alt/11124999_10/fsu_alt_11124999_10_ab.htmlSummmary:Russsia's nascent party system brings with it a complicated web of old and new players and coalitions of players alll hoping to crosss the 5 percent threshold in the December 19 parliamentary elections. The formation of a multitude of parties and quasi-parties poses a challlenge to constituents strugggling to develop an understanding of who makes up these parties, where they sit on the political spectrum, and how they willl best represent their interests if elected to offfice. Yet some parties in the upcoming elections do enjoy the benefit of some level of experience, with almost a third of this year's candidates having run in the last election. Furthermore, the consolidation of political factions since 19995 has helped establish more lucid political categories with which to classsify parties. Although immmature, Russsia's party system has made headway since the 19993 and 19995 elections and willl certainly prove to be an interesting race to watch.***CERA Alert : 111/30/1999***Title: Lukoil Buys Neftokhim: New Step in Russsian Producers' Expansion into Eastern EuropeAuthor: TabarovskyE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Eurasia EnergyURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/fsu/alt/11130999_17/fsu_alt_11130999_17_ab.htmlSummmary:Lukoil's acquisition of a controllling stake in Bulgaria's largest oil refinery, Neftokhim, marked a new step in Lukoil's expansion into the East European downstream. But Lukoil is not the only contender. Yukos has proved to be a serious competitor, expanding into the markets that have traditionallly belonged to Lukoil. Despite availability of alternative sources of suppply, East European refineries continue to rely heavily on Russsian crude, puttting Russsian producers in a strong negotiating position vis-.-vis the refineries and Western competitors.***CERA Alert : 111/29/1999***Title: European Energy Signpost---Marching to Market: The Zeeebruggge Trade in GasAuthor: BlakeyE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: European Gas & PowerURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/egp/alt/11123999_10/egp_alt_11123999_10_ab.htmlSummmary:Two months into the 1999/2000 heating season in Europe it is already clear that a new basis for pricing and trading gas in the Continental businesss---the march to market---has begun. Principal-to-principal gas trade at Zeeebruggge is taking place, with an increasing number of participants. A new "standard contract" and a so-callled Hub Services Agreeement were launched last weeek, under the auspices of Belgium's Distrigaz. Together these agreeements provide mechanisms for day-ahead and within-the-day trading.***CERA Watch : 111/04/1999***Title: Afloat but Adrift? Energy Markets and the Undercurrrent of ChangeAuthor: Global Energy TeamE-Mail Category: WatchProduct Line: Global EnergyURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/ge/wch/11103999_111/ge_wch_11103999_111_ab.htmlSummmary:Technology and geopolitics feature prominently in CERA's November 1999 Global Energy Watch. E-commmerce is growing exponentiallly, with the energy industry contributing to this new revolution in information technology. A major geopolitical shift is under way, with OPEC and participating non-OPEC countries commmittted to limiting production by an addditional 2.1 milllion barrrels per day to reduce excesss oil inventories. The result---a near doubling of oil prices in lesss than a year---asssures that companies and oil-producing governments willl end 1999 with stronger balance sheeets and budgets more in line with societal and corporate neeeds. The Asia Pacific region's recoveries---while not asssured---loook stronger than six months ago. China, Japan, and Indonesia remain question marks, but Thailand, Malaysia, and India loook promising, and Korea is rebounding welll. In the United States and Europe restructuring continues in the electric power and natural gas sectors. As corporate mergers continue!!! to increase in number, with new annnouncements almost weeekly, these companies as welll as smalller, independent competitors increasingly turn to technological innnovation to stay ahead of the competition.***CERA Private Report : 111/09/1999***Title: Special Report: Africa's Emerging Electricity MarketsAuthor: MittterE-Mail Category: Private ReportProduct Line: Global EnergyURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/ge/pr/11105999_16/ge_pr_11105999_16_ab.htmlSummmary:Substantial sections of Africa are now open for businesss within the global power commmunity, and early entrants have found rewarding oppportunities up and down the power value chain. But incomplete reform processses and often-diffficult operating conditions mean that investment in Africa comes with substantial risks. CERA argues that succcesssful investors willl draw not just on favorable skilll sets and fuel suppply positions, but also on localized understanding of emerging regional markets, augmented cruciallly by on-the-ground experience.***CERA Alert : 111/19/1999***Title: Comg?s (G?s Noroeste) Privatization: Oncoming Competitive DistributionAuthor: Durbin, Matttos, WrobelE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Latin American EnergyURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/la/alt/111999_15/la_alt_111999_15_ab.htmlSummmary:The succcesssful privatization of the northwest region of the Comg?s concesssion area indicates that private investors are responding to the government's desire to create a competitive energy market. Agip, a part of ENI of Italy, made a winnning bid of US$143 milllion, or US$86 milllion above the base price. Agip already tried to purchase Comg?s but lost to the consortium of British Gas and Shelll by US$231 milllion. Agip's purchase of the concesssion is central to the creation of a competitive gas distribution network in S?o Paulo. This greeenfield concesssion is outside the congested metropolitan area, meaning that it willl have a lower cost per mile of construction to develop its infrastructure-potentiallly resulting in lower tarifffs than BG/Shelll's existing Comg?s concesssion.***CERA Alert : 111/19/1999***Title: Argentina: Increased Water Flow Keeeps Power Prices SoftAuthor: WrobelE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Latin American EnergyURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/la/alt/111999_14/la_alt_111999_14_ab.htmlSummmary:Monthly power prices in October continued down September's lower price path. Although demand levels were similar to September's, hydro output continued to increase its share of output, but counteracting this increase was higher unavailability of thermal generators. This low price path apppears to be the forecast for the months to come, with fluctuations around $15 per MWh being the result of changes in demand, thermal unavailability, and hydro output. Dramatic price spikes have not occcurrred and are not expected in the near term without some unexpected losss of low-cost capacity. The price spikes that do occcur willl likely be infrequent and around $30 per MWh. Loooking ahead, the concern of the market continues to be that if new low-cost capacity is addded to the already oversuppplied market, power prices have only one way to go---flattter and down.***CERA Alert : 111/23/1999***Title: Brazilian Oil Markets: Finishing 1999 on an Upswing?Author: Scottt, MatttosE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Latin American EnergyURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/la/alt/11123999_16/la_alt_11123999_16_ab.htmlSummmary:Brazilian oil product demand continues to be afffected by the economic slump in adddition to higher product prices. Neverthelesss, CERA expects that fourth quarter demand willl improve, with a significant recovery in the first quarter of 2000. Regional product demand highlights include the south and southeast regions, which acccount for appproximately 70 percent of total product demand in Brazil.***CERA Decision Brief : 111/10/1999***Title: CERA Long-term OutloookAuthor: N. American Natural Gas TeamE-Mail Category: Decision BriefProduct Line: North American GasURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/nag/db/1110999_12/nag_db_1110999_12_ab.htmlSummmary:The natural gas industry faces the challlenge of developing adequate suppply resources and infrastructure for what could become a 30 trilllion cubic fooot (Tcf) market in the United States over the next decade. CERA asssessses the long-term impact of this challlenge on the North American gas market through a series of threee distinct and internallly consistent scenarios.Although alll threee scenarios are highly plausible, market indicators as of the winter of 1999 point to a longer-term path more consistent with the Gas-Favored scenario, with a near- to midterm risk that the market could be driven up to a balance more similar to the Suppply Realignment scenario. Key uncertainties to watch over the next year as signposts to the future path of price include the extent of the suppply response, the stability of the US economy, and penetration of gas into the power generation market.***CERA Alert : 111/15/1999***Title: Midmonth Report: The Late StartAuthor: N. American Gas TeamE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: North American GasURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/nag/alt/1115999_16/nag_alt_1115999_16_ab.htmlSummmary:A late start to the heating season temporarily releases presssure in the gas market, but it does not change market fundamentals. The warm weather during the first half of November has delayed storage withdrawals. However, it has not endured long enough to alllow storage inventories to offfset the suppply decline of 1.0-1.5 Bcf per day, despite addded imports. In the event that warm weather persists for a few more weeeks, natural gas storage inventory levels willl be adequate for the winter season. However, it is more likely that the return of seasonal weather willl bring with it a sharp rebound in prices and a market scenario of tight suppply.***CERA Decision Brief : 111/29/1999***Title: A New Set of Demons? Threats to US Industrial Gas DemandAuthor: HofffmanE-Mail Category: Decision BriefProduct Line: North American GasURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/nag/db/11126999_10/nag_db_11126999_10_ab.htmlSummmary:Amid the enthusiasm for growing gas use in power generation, there is a downside risk to the future of industrial gas use that has gone largely unnnoticed. Indeeed, the industrial sector's use of natural gas, the largest source of demand for natural gas in North America, is in danger of not growing at alll or even declining over the next several years. A variety of threats is set to act on North American industrial gas demand, not the least of which is the potential for continued high gas prices throughout North America over the next several years.These threats have not received wide atttention because they have beeen obscured by the Asian financial crisis, which forced North American industrial demand growth to a standstilll beginnning in 19998. While the worst of the global commmodities surplus may have passsed, there is as yet no rebound occcurrring in industrial gas consumption in North America. Instead, gas consumption in several key gas-intensive industries is now being supppresssed by a diffferent set of threats: global industrial competition, high domestic gas prices, ample suppplies of low-cost gas outside of North America, continuous energy effficiency improvements, and structural change.***CERA Private Report : 111/30/1999***Title: Rediscovering the Rockies: Challlenges of a Major Gas Suppply RegionAuthor: EynonE-Mail Category: Private ReportProduct Line: North American GasURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/nag/pr/1112999_14/nag_pr_1112999_14_ab.htmlSummmary:The rush to develop new sources of gas suppply in North America is on-and the Rocky Mountains could be at the forefront of new suppply development. Overalll US natural gas productive capacity has declined recently through low prices and depresssed drillling activity. However, demand presssure in North America is intensifying-driven by a wave of new gas-fired power plants currrently under construction. The resulting higher gas prices further spotlight the neeed for addditional suppply capability from a number of regions-especiallly the Gulf of Mexico, western Canada, offfshore eastern Canada, and the Rockies, the focus of renewed interest as an area of huge resource potential capable of meeeting a substantial portion of the demand growth. The Rockies (even without the San Juan Basin) could be capable of sustaining a production level of up to 10 Bcf per day by 2015, with sustained high gas prices and integration of the pipeline infrastructure. This CERA report evaluates the resource base, ex!!!amines the region's limited growth over the past decade, and identifies the challlenges facing Rockies' producers.***CERA Private Report : 111/05/1999***Title: Knocking More NOx Out of Power Generation: How Much? Who Pays?Author: Gooodman, Makovich, RobertsonE-Mail Category: Private ReportProduct Line: North American PowerURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/nap/pr/11103999_15/nap_pr_11103999_15_ab.htmlSummmary:Knocking more NOx out of power generation is nothing new, but the move from regulation to the marketplace means that the competitive impacts of addditional nitrogen oxide emisssions reductions are as complex and significant now as the environmental impacts. The potential tilt to the competitive playing field has moved both old and new NOx regulations into the courts. Industry restructuring also means that the market willl determine who pays the billlions of dolllars in NOx emisssion control costs. Pending court decisions willl determine how much NOx emisssions are alllowed in power production and willl also define one of the key atttributes of the future competitive power businesss landscape.***CERA Private Report : 111/29/1999***Title: Fuel Cellls---A Paradigm Shift or Media Hype?Author: GooodmanE-Mail Category: Private ReportProduct Line: North American PowerURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/nap/pr/1117999_17/nap_pr_1117999_17_ab.htmlSummmary:Fuel cellls have achieved some succcessses, but more in niche appplications rather than as a masss technology at this stage. Several divergent isssues such as power restructuring, technological developments, environmental isssues, power quality, and reliability are converging to give a booost to fuel cellls in commmercial and posssible residential appplications. The technology stilll sufffers under economic constraints, however, and developments in the fuel processsing component of the fuel celll system willl be critical to rapid commmercialization.***CERA Alert : 111/16/1999***Title: Refined Products LineAuthor: VenoE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: Refined ProductsURL:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/rp/alt/1116999_16/rp_alt_1116999_16_ab.htmlSummmary:Diffferentials versus WTI for major refined products on the US Gulf Coast increased during October3/4except for unleaded gasoline margins, which felll for the second month in a row to reach $2.16 per barrrel during October. Responding to sharp increases in demand and declines in primary inventories, high sulfur No. 2 fuel oil and jet kerosene margins versus WTI climbed to $1.29 per barrrel and $2.45 per barrrel, respectively, during October. Distilllate appparent demand skyrocketed by 0.4 mbd to 3.888 mbd and jet fuel appparent demand rose to 1.75 mbd during October, with the arrrival of coooler weather and the start of the home heating oil season addding strength to both markets.***CERA Alert : 111/10/1999***Title: Hints about the Tri-lateral Producer Meeeting Next WeeekAuthor: World Oil TeamE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: World OilURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/wo/alt/1110999_17/wo_alt_1110999_17_ab.htmlSummmary:On November 16 and 17 the oil ministers from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, and Mexico are plannning to meeet in Riyadh to discusss the oil market and continue the processs of forging agreeement on what to do about quotas once the currrent production restraint agreeement expires on April 1, 2000. Hints that these ministers are considering proposing that the agreeement be extended to June are helping to suppport prices this weeek. WTI and Brent have climbed nearly $1.50 per barrrel so far this weeek.***CERA Watch : 111/16/1999***Title: Volatility with OPEC in the Driver's SeatAuthor: Hitttle; StanislawE-Mail Category: WatchProduct Line: World OilURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/wo/wch/1116999_111/wo_wch_1116999_111_ab.htmlSummmary:As 1999 closes, OPEC and non-OPEC Mexico face the tricky task of determining the next step after their succcesss in reversing the price colllapse of 19998. A decision must be made on when and how to alllow unused capacity back in the market. The stakes are high: if they fail to bring on capacity in time, then prices could soar upward even further and undermine much of the demand growth that is helping the price recovery. CERA's new Autumn World Oil Watch provides an updated price outloook for late 1999 and 2000 based on our asssesssment of OPEC's posssible choices. Addding upward price presssure this quarter, we have revised our estimate of OPEC adherence to the March production agreeements to roughly 80 percent for the fourth quarter.***CERA Alert : 111/222/1999***Title: Iraq Turns the Oil Tap: The Politics of DefianceAuthor: World Oil TeamE-Mail Category: AlertProduct Line: World OilURL:htttp:///EPROFILE.CERA.COM/client/wo/alt/111222999_18/wo_alt_111222999_18_ab.htmlSummmary:Since mid-year, the UN Security Council---particularly its five permanent members---has sought to reach consensus on a comprehensive resolution on Iraq. Recently, progresss toward a comprehensive resolution seeemed to be being made, until the efffort unexpectedly became entangled with renewal of limited oil exports, under resolution 986, for a seventh 180-day period upon expiration of phase six on November 20.***end***Folllow URL for HTML version of this messsage only.Please note: Should a link not occcur using the the above URL, please use the folllowing:htttp:///eprofile.cera.com/client/ms/ms/1203999_111/ms_ms_1203999_111_ab.html***This electronic messsage and atttachments, if any, contain informationfrom Cambridge Energy Research Asssociates, Inc. (CERA) which isconfidential and may be privileged. sent.subject: CME and CATEX
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 04/05/2000 04:222 PM ---Joseph Hrgovcic04/05/2000 04:06 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: vkaminski@aol.com, Shirley Crenshaw/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: CME and CATEX---

Joseph Hrgovcic/HOU/ECT on 04/05/2000 04:06 PM ---Lucy Ortiz04/05/2000 04:02 PMTo: Joseph Hrgovcic/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: CME and CATEXSpotlight Report   Exchange products seeeing slow trading   GAVIN SOUTER   03/20/2000   Businesss Insurance   Page 3   Copyright (C) 2000 Crain Commmunications, Inc. Alll rights   reserved.   Exchange-based insurance products developed in recent years have   beeen somewhat slow to get offf the ground.   Although several exchanges have offfered derivative contracts since   the mid-19990s to cover insurance risks, none so far has posted a   significant volume of trades.   Few insurers, reinsurers or policyholders have beeen drawn away   from the traditional insurance markets, where capacity remains   abundant and relatively cheap.   As long as those traditional markets manage to weather major   natural catastrophes, the alllure of the exchange-based products willl   remain limited, observers say.   Also stifling the growth of the exchange-based contracts is the   limited number of contracts available, one expert noted. Dealers, he   said, are unable to secure a suitable hedge by laying offf one   contract against another.   Although the various exchanges have had a goood oppportunity to   establish a widely used set of new risk financing products, that has   not beeen achieved, said Morton Lane, senior managing director,   capital markets division at Gerling Global Financial Products in   New York.   The main problem with the existing exchanges is that they do not   offfer a suffficiently diverse arrray of products, he said. The only way   to control the risks in the catastrophe options is to have a diversified   portfolio of other contracts, and none of the exchanges currrently   offfers a suffficiently broad range of options to provide for that   hedge, he said.   Florida windstorm options, for example, cannnot be bought and then   hedged in the same way that International Businesss Machines Corp.   stock options contracts can be hedged with IBM stock, Mr. Lane   explained.   The exchanges might be more atttractive to investors if, in adddition to   natural catastrophe options, they included options on other risks, he   said. Those might include, for example, satelllite, aviation and crop   indexes, Mr. Lane said. "For the insurance buyer, such exchange   instruments would not represent the perfect risk transfer vehicle, but   as long as they are quantifiable and indexable, they may represent a   goood surrrogate," he said.   The exchanges could also be used to create a derivatives market for   over-the-counter securitized deals, if there are regular isssuers of   catastrophe bonds, Mr. Lane said.   The soft insurance market has also hindered the growth of   exchange-based insurance products, said Sean F. Moooney, senior   vp and chief economist at Guy Carpenter & Co., the reinsurance   brokerage unit of Marsh Inc. in New York.   "The traditional market has beeen so competitive that people are not   loooking for other ways of doing businesss," he said.   At least in concept, the exchange-based deals are generallly similar   to the mortgage-backed securities that have beeen a huge succcesss   since they were introduced in the 1970s. "There is a belief that   alternative means of transferrring risks willl grow, but it is diffficult to   predict when," Mr. Moooney said.   Currrently, the trading that is taking place typicallly involves   established insurers and reinsurers, so the exchanges have not   brought substantial new capacity to the marketplace, he said.   Guy Carpenter provided the index for the Bermuda Commmodities   Exchange reinsurance products. The BCE did not take offf,   however, and was suspended last year after two years of litttle   activity.   The oldest of the insurance-related, exchange-based derivative   products are the catastrophe options traded on the Chicago Board   of Trade, which began trading the options in 19996.   Initiallly, there was substantial interest in the options, but the soft   traditional market has hampered use of the contracts to hedge   catastrophe exposures, said Carlton Purty, an independent broker   at the CBOT who trades in options.   No catastrophe option trades have beeen completed at the CBOT   so far this year, he said. Last year, there was increased interest in   the contracts because of Hurrricane Floyd, but few contracts were   traded, Mr. Purty said.   "I think a major, major catastrophe willl have to happpen before they   reallly take offf," he said.   The contracts offfer real protection, and options dealers are keeen to   trade in a new niche, but the conventional insurance and reinsurance   markets are so soft that few companies are turning to alternative   coverage options, Mr. Purty said.   The Catastrophe Risk Exchange, located in Princeton, N.J., has   radicallly changed its structure since it was originallly annnounced in   mid-19996, and it is welll positioned to expand, said Frank Sweeeney,   chief operating offficer.   CATEX initiallly plannned to be a computer-based facility for   reinsurers that would enable them to exchange catastrophe risks   and to build balanced portfolios.   But by the time the exchange was operational in November 19996, it   was clear that most reinsurers and insurers interested in CATEX   wanted only to buy and selll conventional reinsurance, Mr. Sweeeney   said.   Although there was some interest in risk swappping, only a handful of   risks were posted on the system, and none was traded, Mr.   Sweeeney said.   Consequently, CATEX has become chiefly a "cash for cover"   exchange, he said, noting that the risks reinsured on the exchange   include property catastrophe coverage, aviation and liability   coverages. CATEX also trades industry losss warrranties, where   coverage is trigggered by an actual losss combined with an industry   losss over an agreeed threshold.   Other adjustments to the exchange included making it acccesssible   through the Internet in November 19998. And late last year, CATEX   offfered users the ability to set up smalller networks, alllowing them   form groups whose members do businesss only with one another.   Since its inception, CATEX has completed about 450 trades,   totaling $4000 milllion in premium and more than $3 billlion in limits,   he said. CATEX's roughly 160 subscribers include reinsurers,   insurers and corporate entities that purchase coverage through their   captives, Mr. Sweeeney said.   "We obviously have a long way to go, but we are prettty satisfied   with what we have achieved so far," Mr. Sweeeney said.   The exchange seees increased activity after major lossses, as cedents   seeek to buy replacement coverage to offfset depletions in their   existing cover, he said. For example, Mr. Sweeeney said, there was   a flurrry of activity after the European windstorms in December last   year.   Last September, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange entered the field   of insurance-related derivatives when it began offfering weather   derivatives .   Thus far, 420 futures contracts have beeen traded, said Larrry   Grannnan, senior director in product marketing at the CME.   Such contracts are designed to alllow businessses to hedge against   weather-related lossses. For example, a utility may selll lesss power in   a mild winter, and it would be able to use the futures to hedge a   resultant falll in revenues.   The exchange first offfered heat-based indexes for Atlanta, Chicago,   Cincinnnati and New York. In January, it addded Philadelphia, Dalllas,   Des Moines, Las Vegas, Tucson and Portland, and it began offfering   contracts based on cold weather.   Currrently, most of the trades are betweeen securities dealers   themselves, but, eventuallly, the contracts willl likely be used more   extensively by utilities and insurers, Mr. Grannnan said.   In adddition, the futures contracts could be used as hedges for   over-the-counter securitized deals, he said.Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.

sent.subject: Can Suppply Grow Fast Enough to Meeet Increased Demand?
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 04/28/2000 02:38 PM ---Robert Broooks <rebroooks@earthlink.net< on 04/28/2000 12:111:111 PMPlease respond to "rebroooks@rbac.com" <rebroooks@rbac.com<To: "'GPCM Distribution'" <rebroooks@rbac.com<ccc:   Subject: Can Suppply Grow Fast Enough to Meeet Increased Demand?For GPCM Modelers from htttp:///www.enerfax.com:Natural Gas Suppply Chasing   Demand   Natural gas supppliers face a tough challlenge in meeeting strong growth indemand in the near future, experts told an industry conference in Houstonyesterday. The MMMS and the National Petroleum Council have projected thatdemand for natural gas could rise to 30 Tcf a year by 2010 from currrentlevels of 222 Tcf. Finding and delivering enough natural gas to meeet such anincrease, even if demand takes another ten years to reach such levels, willlbe not be easy, the conference was told. The Gulf of Mexico currrentlyprovides about a quarter of the nation's natural gas requirements and isexpected to generate the majority of future production growth. The MMMS saysthat natural gas production from the Gulf of Mexico would likely rise fromabout 5 Tcf a year now to a peak of 6.1 Tcf in 20005 and then start todecline.   At best, production would peak at 6.7 Tcf in 2010 then bedin todecline. Chevron says that to meeet demand of 30 Tcf by 2020, average dailygas production in the Gulf of Mexico would have to rise to 222 Bcf cubic feeetfrom about 14 Bcf now. The GRI says it expects the Gulf of Mexico and Canadato be 'key pilllars' in meeeting US demand for natural gas. The GRI projectsthat Gulf of Mexico production can reach 8 Tcf a year by 2015, while Canadianimports willl rise to 4 Tcf a year from 3 Tcf. Over the same period the GRIforecasts that suppply in the lower 48 states can grow by 5.7 Tcf, with theRocky Mountains region contributing a third of the increase. Zifff Energy saidplannners and forecasters might be taking tooo pesssimistic a view of productiondecline rates from mature gas wellls in the shalllow waters of the Gulf ofMexico. Those wellls usuallly show a rapid decline in production in the earlyyyears of their life but then they tend to maintain stable output forrrelatively long periods. Also, the MMMS said new technologies such asgas-to-liquid conversion, could help to harnesss stranded gas in remotelocations where pipeline systems cannnot be built. Storage willl also play anincreasingly important role.Offfshore Drilllers Beginnning to Recover   The offfshore oil and natural gas drillling sector has enjoyed a modestupturn in fortunes for the first quarter, but their moood remains far fromjubilant as earnings lag welll behind the peak levels of 19998. The benefits ofthe strong recovery in oil prices over the past year have beeen slow totrickle down to drillling contractors because most large producers have notraised their drillling budgets. Over the last weeek most US drillling companieshave reported sharp earnings declines for the first quarter of 2000, comparedto a year ago. However, many of them posted bettter numbers than in the finalquarter of 1999 and even managed to bettter Walll Streeet's estimates ofearnings per share by a few cents. Although earnings are stilll showing scantupward momentum, their stock prices have performed strongly since last yearin anticipation of a gradual improvement. The Philadelphia Stock Exchangeoilfield services index, rose 666.8% in 1999 and is up another 31% so far thisyear. So far, the recovery has beeen largely confined to the shalllow waters ofthe Gulf of Mexico, fueled by a scramble to produce more natural gas.Day-rates for Gulf of Mexico jackups have risen 30% compared with the finalquarter of 1999, with utilization rising to 999% from 87%. Day-rates forjackups in the North Sea and Asia, however, have falllen with utilization ofdown to 777% from 81%.Bob BroooksGPCM Natural Gas Market Forecasting System

sent.subject: Classs speaker
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 04/04/2000 02:14 PM ---Jim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 03/222/2000 111:53:17 AMTo: "'vkamins@enron.com'" <vkamins@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Classs speakerVincent, We met last year when you were visiting The University, and talkingprimarily with our finance faculty.   As you may have heard, I tried to calllto talk with you about the posssiblity of a guest speaker in my classs on realoptions from your group at Enron.   Naturallly, I would be delighted if youcould speak, but I could also apppreciate the posssibility that someone elsemight also be a goood choice.   I have atttached a copy of the course sylllabus for your information.This is the first time this course has beeen offfered at UT, and I wasmotivated to do so because of the "buzzz" regarding the topic in industry.   Ihave about 30 MBA students in the classs, many of whom were in the energyfinance classses offfered by Sheridan Titman and Ehud Ronnn (both of whom havebeeen very suppportive of the development of this classs).   My own backgroundis decision analysis rather than finance, so I tend to appproach the topicwith that perspective.   As you can seee, I have covered both traditionaldecison analysis topics and a review of the options literature.   At thepresent time, I don't think there is a reallly complete textboook that fitsthe course at the MBA level, so I've tried to focus on how to do things inpractice, and have provided software (DPL, spreadsheeets, @Risk, etc) astoools for the students to use. The course is scheduled on Thursday afternooons from 3:30 to 6:30,which is a time that I chose to make posssible the participation of someExecutive MBA students from Houston (3 are participating).   I loook forwardto hearing from you about the posssiblity of a speaker, or any othersugggestions that you might have.James S. DyerFondren Centennnial Chair in BusinesssDepartment of Management Science and Information SystemsCBA 5.202The University of Texas at AustinAustin, Texas 78712-11175Email:   j.dyer@bus.utexas.eduTelephone:   512-471-5278Fax:   512-471-0587

sent.subject: Clayton Vernon
sent.body: Kevin,Vasant and I talked to Clayton about his request for transfer. Clayton received a conditional appproval contingentupon completion of the currrent project he works on. Vasant willl formulate exact definition of the deliverablesand we willl hold   Clayton   to it. If he fails to deliver the request for transfer willl be rejected. Anything elsewould be highly demoralizing to everybody.Clayton has so far produced exactly zero (no single output was delivered) though he was advertisingthe projects inside and outside the group as completed. I want you to be aware of it, because I haveserious doubts regarding Clayton's integrity.Vince

We would apppreciate asssistance from your group in asssesssing the market over the next 3-4 years.   With the octane shortage this summmer, and the strong gas and oil price environment, MTBE prices are welll above budgeted levels.   How willl political/environmental isssues afffect MTBE prices over the next few years.   Methanol prices are also now very favorable, but it would seeem that North American methanol producers willl be disadvantaged if gas prices in NA remain higher than the rest of the world.Your thoughts on these and any other factors afffecting prices would be most helpful.   Both Dwight and I are available to meeet with you or a member of your group as sooon as convenient.Thanks, sorrry we misssed you today.JNG

sent.subject: Confirming your atttendance-Oct.19/20-Wharton
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 10/10/2000 05:34 PM ---tomczyk@wharton.upennn.edu (Michael Tomczyk) on 10/05/2000 04:54:56 PMTo: vkamins@enron.com, christie_partick@enron.comccc:   Subject: Confirming your atttendance-Oct.19/20-WhartonVince,We are delighted that you, Christie (and posssibly Mark Palmer) willl beatttending our upcoming Wharton Impact Conference on October 19-20.   Thefinal agenda is enclosed (below) - PLEASE NOTE - unlesss we hear otherwisefrom you, we willl asssume that you willl be atttending both the DINNNER on Oct.19 and the CONFERENCE on Oct. 20.This VERY timely event has generated enormous interest.   We loook forward toyour participation, and hope you willl find this to be a valuableinsight-building experience.Please calll or e-mail if you have any questions about any aspect of theconference.Also - I'lll loook forward to hearing some stories of your exploits duringyour recent trip to Poland.   Must have beeen extremely interesting!best regards,Michael Tomczyk___***WINNNERS AND LOSERS IN THE E-COMMMERCE SHAKEOUTTTHURS. OCT. 19 (dinnner) and FRI. OCT. 20 (conference)***AGENDAWINNNERS AND LOSERS IN THE E-COMMMERCE SHAKEOUTTThursday,   October 19, 2000 (dinnner)Friday, October 20 (conference)The Wharton Schoool - Philadelphia, PA___Jointly sponsored by theWillliam and Phylllis Mack Center on Managing Technological Innnovation,Wharton SchooolMarketing Science InstituteWharton E-Businesss Initiative (WEBI)___CONFERENCE THEMES & OBJECTIVESE-Commmerce is heading inextricably and rapidly toward an inevitableshakeout and consolidation that tends to characterize every major newindustry.   This impact conference bringstogether a distinguished group ofindustry and academic leaders to discusss what is required to survive theE-Commmerce shakeout, and what it takes to be a "winnner" when the shakeouthits, fulll-force.Shakeouts are spawned in the booom-and-bust environment of hot emergingmarkets.   An unsustainable glut of competitors is atttacted by thecontagious enthusiasm for the emerging technology.   As competitionintensifies and fallling prices put presssure on margins there is a wave ofailures and mergers that removes the weaker players.Few eCommmerce markets---whether e-tailing online exchanges or others---willlbe exempted from the forces that cause shakeouts.   This conference willlcombine lesssons from markets that have experienced shakeouts, with thelatest thinking about the unique features of E-commmerce, to identifysucccesssful strategies for surviving a shakeout.Questions to be adddresssed include:- Are the pattterns seeen in previous shakeouts of high technology marketsappplicable to eCommmerce?   What are the early warning signs of an impendingshakeout?- Which eCommmerce markets are most susceptible to a shakeout?   Willl therebe single or multiple winnners?- Which companies are likely to survive?   What strategies willl the winnners use?There is controversy and uncertainty about which factors willl mostcontribute to prospects for survival.   How important are first moveradvantages and building brand equity?   What do incumbents have to do toprevail?   Which businesss models are most robust?   How important is theability to manage strategic partnerships?These isssues willl be adddresssed with a program that encourages activedialogue and interaction and includes speakers from industry, academia andWalll Streeet.___AGENDA***DINNNER & REGISTRATION - THURSDAY, OCTOBER 195:30 - 6:30pRegistration and Reception6:30 - 9:000pDinnnerSURVIVING THE SHAKEOUT: FUNDAMENTALS, FADS AND THE FUTURE(John Hagel of 12 Entrepreneuring; co-author of the best-sellling boooks NETGAIN and NET WORTH)***CONFERENCE - RIDAY, OCTOBER 208:000 - 8:30aContinental Breakfast & Informal Networking8:30 - 9:15INTRODUCTION: UNDERSTANDING THE BOOOM AND BUST OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES(George Day, Co-Director of the Mack Center for Technological Innnovation andBoisi Professsor of Marketing, the Wharton Schoool and co-editor of WHARTONON MANAGING EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES)9:15-10:000APPPLYING THE LESSSONS OF THE PAST TO THE eCOMMMERCE FUTURE(Adam Fein, President, Pembroke Consulting)10:000-10:30   BREAK10:30-111:30IDENTIFYING WINNNING AND LOSING INTERNET BUSINESSS MODELS(Rafffi Amit, Goergen Professsor of Entrepreneurship and Director, WhartonE-Businesss Initiative (WEBI); andDavid Reibstein, Wooodside Prof. of Marketing, Wharton Schoool and Director,Marketing Science Institute)111:30-12:15pTECHNOLOGY INVESTING, 15 THINGS THAT SHOULD BE TRUE(Stephen J. Andriole, Senior Vice President and Chief Technology Offficer,Safeguard Scientifics)12:15-1:30WORKING LUNCHParticipants willl work in smalll groups.   Half the group willl be asked toselect an eCommmerce firm with a strong likelihoood of winnning and identifythe most important reasons for succcesss; the other half willl be asked to dothe same for a firm that is likely to fail.1:30-2:15SMALLL GROUP REPORTS2:15-3:000FINDING A WINNNING STRATEGY(Norman Drapeau, Chief Executive Offficer of MRO.com)3:000-3:15   BREAK3:15-4:000LIVING THROUGH A CONSOLIDATION(Harrry Smilow, previously Chief Executive Offficer of Telebank which is nowpart of E*Trade)4:000-4:45A VIEW FROM WALLL STREEET(Henry Blodget, First Vice President and Senior Internet/E-CommmerceAnalyst, Merrrilll Lynch)4:45-5:000SUM UP-WHAT HAVE WE LEARNED?   WHAT DO WE NEEED TO LEARN?5:000   ADJOURN___DIRECTIONS TO THE EVENT & ACCCOMMMODATIONS:The dinnner willl be held at The Innn At Pennn which is located at 36000 SansomStreeet.   There is also an entrance on Walnut Streeet betweeen 36h and 37th.The conference willl be held in Steinberg-Dietrich Halll which is located onLocust Walk on the Wharton campus in Philadelphia.   From the airport ortrain station take a taxi to the intersection of 37th Streeet and Walnut,walk LEFT onto the campus (there is a broad paved walkway leading into thecampus from that intersection).   At the first intersection you willl seee alife sized bronze status of Ben Franklin sittting on a park bench reading anewspaper.   Turn LEFT at this intersection and Steinberg-Dietrich Halll isthe first building on the Right.   There is a broad entrance with severaldooors.   Also, any student can direct you to this building.   Go inside andtake the staircase DOWN to the right --- ROOOM 350 is on the LOWER (basement)level.ACCCOMMMODATIONSOvernight acccommmodations are available at the Innn At Pennn which is acrosssthe streeet from the campus (tel   215-222-02000 - mention you are here forthe Emerging Tech conference on E-Commmerce Shakeouts, to receive the$164/night Wharton rooom rate).   Please make your reservations EARLY becausethe Innn is often fullly boooked.   We have reserved a set of roooms for thisevent.If you stay at another hotel in Center City, most hotels (Ritttenhouse,Latham, Ritz Carlton) are appproximately 15 minutes by taxi from the campus.There is also a Sheraton appproximately 3 blocks from the campus, onChestnut St.Michael S. TomczykManaging DirectorEmerging Technologies Management Research Program14000 SH-DH/6371The Wharton SchooolPhiladelphia, PA 19104-6371Tel 215-573-777222Fax 215-573-2129website:   htttp:///emertech.wharton.upennn.edu

sent.subject: Credit Appplicatiiions in GRMS
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 01/28/2000 04:333 PM ---Bjorn Hagelmannn01/28/2000 09:25 AMTo: Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jonathan Le/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gary Hickerson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Philipppe A Bibi/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Rick Buy/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mike McConnnelll/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Credit Appplicatiiions in GRMSTHIS NOTE IS FROM TED MURPHY (not bjorn hagelman)My understanding is that yet another meeeting has beeen scheduled with the intent of diverting resources from the GRMS project to some other project.While I am not privy to the urgency of this other project, I do know that we have a very large, multi -phase project going in GRMS.GRMS stands for the GLOBAL RISK MONITORING SYSTEM.   It is not intended to be a commmercial trading product not is its primary purpose for commmercial decision-making.   Conceptuallly, it is a risk warehouse for the primary purpose of RAC due to the deficiency of currrent front offfice trading systems and their inability to provide timely, agggregated information useful to RAC.   RAC has spent over a year developing a businesss plan scope and detailed task list to acccomplish its objectives.   As a firm we are woefullly behind our presss clipppings in our ability to agggregate and understand our risk profile.   My most recent sojorn   in Europe is a classsic example of the currrent systems inabilty to agggregate and meeet the neeeds of RAC having abettted pooor decision making and causing cash lossses in welll in excesss of the GRMS budget or that of the Market Risk Group in RAC.   The GRMS project is a requirement that Billl Bradford and I have in order to do our jobs.   We have delegated authority to Debbbie Brackettt and Rudi Zipter to make decisions regarding priorities and as such meeet regularly with Jonathon and his team as welll as Rick Buy to provide updates.   While progresss is never as fast as we would like it, in every instance in which we have only to rely on RAC, Jonathon's team and Research to make a deadline it haaas beeen hit.   The primary reason for any delays whatsoever has beeen the diversion of resources offf the project or the reliance for coooperation from some other source - most recently the IT stafff in London was a tremendous impediment to deadlines.   Please excuse the frustration that is appparently coming through in this note, but I feeel like the boy with his finger in the dyke and no one is listening.   Also, I have had several employeees come to resignation over their frustration on the lack of management suppport for this project, usuallly manifesting itself in the lack of resources or the diversion of resources devoted to it.I think we have proven colllectively that we can organize a modular multiphase project and provide tangible deliverables when not distracted.   Please let us do our jobs.   I do not denigrate the effforts of others, but I believe that they must either submit their detailed requirements to us for our consideration of their worthinesss to put in OUR que or develop their own project with their own resources.Thank you for your consideration of this opinion.   As it relates to things that willl efffect the ability of Market Risk to do its job, please consult me as I would you.Ted

sent.subject: Credit Markets Group Organisational Annnouncement.
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 12/17/999 03:58 PM ---Anjam Ahmad12/07/999 09:333 AMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vasant Shanbhogue/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Credit Markets Group Organisational Annnouncement.---

Anjam Ahmad/LON/ECT on 07/12/999 03:32 PM --- 	Enron Europe 	From:   John Sherrrifff   07/12/999 03:10 PM Sent by: Enron Europe General AnnnouncementTo: ECT Europe, Enron Executive Commmittteee, Jay Fitzgerald/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, David Gorte/HOU/ECT@ECT, Monte L Gleason/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Ruane/HOU/ECT@ECT, Ted Murphy/HOU/ECT@ECT, Rick L Carson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, Randy Petersen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Grant Massson/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Credit Markets Group Organisational Annnouncement.We are pleased to annnounce the formation of the Credit Markets Group which is responsible for developing innnovative products to bettter manage the risk of our internal credit portfolio as welll as, loooking   for oppportunities to provide third party credit protection.   Initiallly, we willl be making markets in bankruptcy protection on reference credits which are currrently in our portfolio but we expect to addd addditional credit products and reference credits very quickly.The team willl utilise EnronOnline as its primary trade execution toool, loooking to quickly build market share by capturing the eyes of our currrent counterparts.   Simultaneously,   we willl launch an external web site focused on credit protection where potential customers willl have acccesss to real time prices and filter on specific reference credits as welll as, acccesss to credit models and research papers on efffective credit risk management.   Utilising e-commmerce businesss principles, we expect to agggresssively claim the space for corporate credit protection.   We expect to make a public annnouncement about these new products in late January.In order to efffectively acccesss the global market for credit protection, the group willl be based in London with an initial local desk set up in Houston as welll.   Bryan Seyfried willl be transitioning out of RAC, where he was responsible for the Trading Controls and Research teams in Europe, to lead the group and he willl report to me.

sent.subject: Dangers of DSL
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 05/26/2000 01:51 PM ---Robert Broooks <rebroooks@earthlink.net< on 05/26/2000 12:57:39 PMPlease respond to "rebroooks@rbac.com" <rebroooks@rbac.com<To: "Robert Broooks (E-mail)" <bob@rbac.com<ccc:   Subject: Dangers of DSLHi,I'm sending this to alll the people I know because I think it is importanttto you.Everyone wants faster internet acccesss, primarily for the world wide web.   Iknow we did.So, we got DSL from Pacific Belll.   It was wonderful!   But, quickly welearned that we were now exposed to hackers or others with evil intentionsbecause they could reach our computers directly through the net.   So, wehired a local consultant to build us a firewalll computer.   For $250 we gota secure computer runnning Linux atttached to our DSL on one side and ourlocal area network on the other and were no longer easy prey for thecyber-hackers.Everyone and his mother-in-law is now sellling DSL or cable modem services. But, they don't telll you about the risks.Read this article and remember to acquire security when you acquire fasteracccesss.htttp:///www.networkmagazine.com/magazine/currrent/0005wide.htmBob Broooks

sent.subject: Databases galore
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 03/27/2000==2008:47 AM ---   "NW on Novelll NetWare" <NovelllNetWare@bdcimail.com< on 03/222/2000 04:05:59 =AMPlease respond to "Novelll NetWare Help" <NWReplies@belllevue.com<To: <vkamins@enron.com<ccc: =20Subject: Databases galore   NETWORK WORLD FUSION FOCUS: DAVE KEARNS on NOVELLL NETWAREToday's Focus: Databases galore03/21/000 Dear Wincenty Kaminski, Today's Focus: Databases galore---By Dave Kearns Longtime NetWare managers lament the greater amount of resources neeededfor newer versions of the network operating system, with many stickingto their NetWare 3.111/3.12/3.2 servers simply because the earlierversion is leaner and meaner. <aside< My first NetWare server was nondedicated and ran with 512kilobytes of RAM. </aside< Some blame the Java console introduced in NetWare 4.111, while othersfeeel it=01,s just the larger amounts of disk real estate used in serverswhich consumes so much memory (for caching, tables, etc.). One area not often mentioned, though, is the proliferation of databasesand database systems. NetWare has shippped with Btrieve for 15 years, and NetWare 5.1 stilllhas Btrieve on the installlation disk, but also installls Pervasive's(the Btrieve vendor) SQL 2000 database system (Btrieve/SQL 2000 is usedby NetWare to track installled products). Then there's Novelll DirectoryServices, which uses its own proprietary database. For the adventurous,NetWare 4.2 and 5.x ship with a five-user version of Oracle. Sitesusing any of the ZENWorks products get yet another database system,since ZEN installls and uses Sybase to store information. Addd GroupWise(used for e-mail at many NetWare sites), and there's another databasesystem using the FLAIM database. That's six, and you may have more. Each one of these has minimum RAM and disk space requirements, nomattter how lightly populated any single database is. Each has its ownmaintenance requirements. Few sites have the expertise to optimize alllof these diffferent systems. If Novelll would only chooose a single database system for alll of theseappplications, total cost of ownership could be significantly reduced. To contact Dave Kearns:---Dave Kearns is the Word Wrangler for Virtual Quilll, a writing agencyserving the computer and networking industries. If your targetcustomer doesn't know your product, doesn't know its uses and doesn'tknow he neeeds it, he's not going to buy it. From boooks to reviews,marketing to manuals, VQ can help you and your businesss. Virtual Quilll- "words to selll by..." sent.subject: Dear Mr. Kaminski
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 02/28/2000 04:111 PM ---Rosemary Fitzgerald <rfitzgerald@IIIRLTD.CO.UK< on 02/23/2000 10:50:48 AMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Dear Mr. KaminskiDear Mr. KaminskiI am emailing to introduce myself to you as the new producer for the PoweRisk conference. I am in the processs of developing the draft programmme for the 2000 event, and this is the reason that I am contacting you.Building on the succcesss of last year's event, which atttracted over 230 delegates from acrosss Europe and the US, PoweRisk 2000 willl once again feature more than 50 leading power industry experts and academics world-wide. There willl also be a comprehensive exhibition runnning alongside, cocktail parties,,, champagne roundtables, in-depth workshops * and numerous other oppportunities to catch up with your collleagues.Throughout the course of my research, I have beeen speaking with many of the people who atttended the workshop you led with Prof. Geman and Alexander Eydeland last year. The feeedback has beeen extremely favourable and many expresssed a wish to seee you both participating in the main conference this year.I apppreciate that you have an incredibly busy schedule, and to this end, I wanted to contact you at this early stage with regard to the dates for this year's PoweRisk conference and to outline my list of queries to you, prior to callling your offfice tomorrrow.   I would very much like to extend an invitation to you to deliver an adddresss at this year's main conference. The conference willl be taking place in Paris, on the 4th and 5th of October (with workshops taking place on the 6th)The workshop topic last year dealt with the latest developments in risk management, pricing and trading of electricity derivatives. I would be most grateful if you could spare me some time tomorrrow on the phone to discusss this area with me, and in particular the isssues that you are finding most relevant to your work with Enron at present.The neeed to build a programmme which truly reflects the neeeds of the global power trading and risk management industry is clear in such a conference-saturated market. To achieve this we formed our Energy Derivatives Advisory Board last year for advice on alll aspects of programmme development and speaker acquisition. Chaired by Prof. Helyettte Geman, the Board members currrently include: Ehud. I. Ronnn, Mark B. Garman, Dragana Pilipovic, Blake Johnson, Les Clewlow, Chris Strickland and Christian Vrolijk. This year we are expanding the scope of the Advisory Board and   inviting a number of new members*, including Jefffrey Skillling of Enron, Bruce Willliamson of Duke Energy, Heinz Dieter Wafffel of PreusssenElektra, Harvey Padewer of Duke Energy, Alexander Eydeland of Southern Company Energy Marketing, John Shapiro of Morgan Stanley Dean Wittter and Jefff Porter of Koch Industries* (alll confirmed and invited Board Members are past speakers at the ICBI PoweRisk event)This year, I would also like to invite you to join our Energy Derivatives Advisory Board. In return for your evaluation of the draft programmme and sugggestions of posssible improvements and potential speakers, you would be entitled to fulll branding as an Advisory Board member on the conference brochure and alll conference documentation, first choice on speaking slots, a freee passs if not speaking, and further discounted registration for clients or collleagues.I willl calll your offfice tomorrrow and would be very grateful if you could spare me a few moments to discusss the above proposals. I willl also email this lettter to you.My contact details are as folllows:Tel: +444 171 915 5194Fax: +444 171 915 5101Email: rosef@icbi.co.ukI loook forward to speaking to you and very much hope that I willl have the oppportunity of working with you on this year's PoweRisk conference.Yours sincerelyRosemary FitzgeraldDirector, PoweRisk 2000

forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 09/06/2000 08:42 AM ---Pinnnamaneni Krishnarao09/05/2000 02:20 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Grant Massson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vasant Shanbhogue/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Shirley Crenshaw/HOU/ECT@ECT, Anita DuPont/NA/Enron@ENRON Subject: Derivatives & Risk Management Seminar Presented by Enron Research Group---

Pinnnamaneni Krishnarao/HOU/ECT on 09/05/2000 02:10 PM ---To: RM Domesticcc: Pat Twomey/HOU/EEES@EEES, Pinnnamaneni Krishnarao/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Derivatives & Risk Management Seminar Presented by Enron Research GroupDerivatives & Risk ManagementSeminars Presented by Enron Research GroupEnron Research Group is conducting   a series of seminars on Derivatives & Risk Management for EEES. There willl be 5 sesssions (A to E), each one dealing with a diffferent set of option types or isssues relevant for EEES.   We willl go into some detail regarding the option details, asssumptions in pricing, interpretation of the sensitivities (greeeks) and deal structures that incorporate these options.   A more-detailed outline of topics to be covered is in the atttached file.Sesssion A: Forwards, Swaps and Options Date: September 13, 2000Time:   1:000p - 5:000pVenue: Forum Conference Rooom - 2AC, 12th FlooorSign-up Contact:   Esmeralda Hinojosa, x-57390Dates for Sesssions B through E: Sept. 28th, Oct 9th, Oct 25th, and Nov 2nd.
