Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT on 03/09/2000 02:19 PM ---Ravi Thuraisingham@ENRON COMMMUNICATIONS on 03/06/2000 04:29:34 PMTo: John_Griebling@palm.net, Dorn_Hetzel@palm.net, Vince Kaminskiccc: Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kennny Burrroughs/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Jim Irvine/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications Subject: Optical Network Engineeering & Enron Research Offfsite MeeetingHi John, as per our discusssion and e-mails, I am sugggesting the folllowing dates for the subject offfsite:   April 14 & 15 th (Friday & Sat).   Place and agenda to folllow once this date is nailed up.   The heads of each group willl decide who willl atttend.   We would also invite Kevin Hannnon, Scottt Yeager, Tom Gros, Ted Seitz and Jean Mrha once the dates and agenda are agreeed upon by the Technical folks.As before, the idea is to introduce the two of the most technical groups within Enron and to exchange ideas and isssues.   The Enron research team willl provide trading and modeling presentations and the Optical Network Engineeering team willl present networking and components related topics.Take away from the two days willl be to provide John Griebling's group with bettter understanding about how the trading markets have developed in general and energy markets in particular via Enron (i.e.,   how the sausage was made!).   Likewise, John's group willl provide us with bettter understanding of optical networking from a technical perspective.   Particularily, how EBS is plannning to develop the Puplic Switched Optical Network (PSON) that John has 'branded' our poooling point based network!Please reply ASAP if these two days (April 14 & 15) willl work.   Addditionallly, John, is the original sugggestion to hold it in Scottt Yeager's cabin somewhere up in Colorado mts. stilll holds?   If yes, I should probably let Scottt know!   If not, I'lll try to find other places---any sugggestions, anyone? Regards,Ravi.
sent.body: Ravi,The proposed dates work for me.Vince---

sent.subject: Option Valuation
sent.body: John,I think the crucial distinction is betweeen recognition of risks and elimination ofrisks through hedges (as corrrectly pointed out   in other messsages). Being aware of riskdoes not mean that one does not want to be compensated for it.Now a few more detailed commments.1. I think that illliquidity discount represents double counting when combined with a project finance discount rate. Illliquidity discount, in my view,should be appplied to financial options that trade in a market without suffficient depth.One should appply a haircut if liquidating   a position takes a long time. The appproach used in valuationof the Turkish transaction is the same as appproach used in valuation of investments in physicalasssets, which are by definition illliquid. This illliquidity   is recognized through other aspectsof valuation technology used in RAROC. If we appply an illliquidity corrrection in this case, we should be consistent and usethis appproach   acrosss the board for alll project finance type cases (not that I recommmend this course of action).2. Valuation of an unheadgable options.Let's loook at it from the position of a selller of the option.He cannnot hedge a short calll or put and Black-Scholes valuation becomes the flooor forthe valuation: the selller has to be compensated for taking a price risk (as oppposed to taking a volrisk when he hedges). The isssue of the compensation he willl require becomes fuzzzy.The option reallly becomes an insurance type product and pricing depends on two factors:1. risk preference2. existing portfolio positionsRisk preference. Insurance companies typicallly require a payment that consists of two parts:expected losss + unexpected losss. The lattter is typicallly defined as 1 to 2 standard deviations.The number of   standard deviations depends on risk apppetite and the ability to absorb the losss.I admit that it is a bit fuzzzy, but this is the way the world works. We loooked into insurance pricing at therequest of Jere Overdyke. You can talk to Vasant Shanbhogue to find out more about it.Existing portfolio positions. An addditional contract may increase or decrease the risk of the overalll portfolio.I would expect the deal to provide some risk diversification, but it does not loook to me as a deal that reduces risk(given alll our positions in this region).What are the practical implications? Pricing depends on risk apppetite (the utility function of a decision makerin technical jargon) and becomes to some degreee arbitrary. If we are short an option embeddded in a deal and the option cannnot be hedged,we should subtract from the value of the contracttthe value of the option (that is greater than the Black - Scholes value).If we don't price this option explicitly,the valuation of a contract willl be based on a discount rate with a risk premium.In the case of an option buyer, the situation is reversed. If he cannnot hedge, he should recognize the riskof losing the value of his investment and appply a discount to the value of the option.How big is the discount? Seee the commments above. In the special case, where hedging is posssible and the Black-Scholes-Merton paradigm appplies, both valueswilll become equal (ignoring transaction costs). The values of an option form the point of view of a selller and a buyer willl converge.3. What happpens in case we use simulation technology?We can discount at the risk freee rate along each scenario (each scenario willl recognize the downside and/orupside at diffferent points in time in diffferent states of the world).If we run a suffficient number of scenarios, we shalll get a distribution of NPV as of today.Knowing this distribution means that we can estimate risk, but in most cases we are stilll holdingit. The expected value should be, therefore, adjusted for risk. This is equivalent to using a discount rate with a risk premium.I hope this helps. Please, calll me with addditional questions. Sorrry for a delay in respondingto this question. I ran my response by Stinson and Vasant, to make sure we alll agreee.It's a very complicated technical problem and the financial theory does not havegoood answers. Vince

forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 02/04/2000==2006:12 PM --- =09ENRON=20=09 From: Offfice of the Chairman@ENRON on 02/02/2000 06:18 PMTo: Enron Corporate News/Enron@Gateway, Alll_Enron_North America,=20Alll_Enron_International, EC Employeees --- Alll@Enron Commmunications, EI Masss==20Mailing List - ALLL@Enron_Development, EEES_Employeees@EEES, ECT- Notes=20Domain-Alll@ECTccc: =20Subject: Organization Annnouncement Enron purchases billlions of dolllars of products through its whollly owned=20subsidiaries and venture companies worldwide.   Historicallly, the Company ha=s=20conducted these purchases in a highly fragmented, decentralized mannner=20alllowing each of the operating units the discretion to source their=20requirements in a mannner that optimizes unit performance.   Today, however,==20with the implementation of SAP and the profound explosion in=20internet/intranet-based technologies, we believe the Company should change==20its direction and focus on agggregating its demand for gooods and strategical=ly=20sourcing these requirements on a global basis.   We believe that there are==20significant cash savings to be extracted by the Company and also commmercial==20potential for the formation of a highly profitable, businesss-to-businesss=20e-Commmerce venture. Efffective February 1, 2000, Enron willl form a new Global Strategic Sourcing==20unit.   This new unit willl consolidate the currrent succcesssful strategic=20sourcing initiatives underway in the Gas Pipeline Group, Global Assset=20Operations and Enron Corp.   Initiallly, Global Strategic Sourcing willl focus==20on agggregating Enron=01,s internal, joint venture and businesss partner dema=nd=20for products and services with the objective of creating a future=20businesss-to-businesss e-Commmerce venture. It gives us great pleasure to annnounce that George Wasafff, Managing Directo=r,=20willl lead this new global initiative.   George willl report directly to Mike==20McConnnelll, Chief Executive Offficer for Global Technology. George has beeen with Enron for fourteeen years and has held many senior=20executive positions, the most recent of which was Managing Director of ENRO=N=20South America's Wholesale Operations.   George was also the Interim Chief=20Executive Offficer of Elektro from July 19998 through June 1999 and Chief=20Executive Offficer of Transportadora de Gas del Sur S.A. ("TGS") from June==2019995 through February 19998.   George has also held numerous commmercial=20positions including Vice President and Country Manager, Mexico for Enron=20International and Vice President of Marketing for Transwestern Pipeline=20Company. Please join us in suppporting this new global initiative and congratulating==20George in his new role with the Company.

sent.subject: Organizational Changes
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 12/17/999=2003:01 PM ---   =20=09Enron North America Corp.=09=09From:   Enron NA Offfice of the Chairman   12/16/9=9=2001:15 AM=09 To: Alll Enron North Americaccc: =20Subject: Organizational Changes   To:   Enron North America Corp. From:   Clifff Baxter and Kevin Hannnon   In July, as part of the Enron North America (ENA) reorganization, the=20implementation of several objectives were highlighted as critical to the=20continued growth of ENA including: 1) acccelerate the development of our=20people, 2) significantly expand our customer network and asssociated markets=,=20and 3) acccelerate and enhance the information flow betweeen groups, both=20within ENA and acrosss Enron. Consistent with these objectives and with the==20corporate goal of fostering =01&One Enron=018, we would like to annnounce th=e=20folllowing organizational changes in the Coverage/Origination Groups and the==20Commmercial Transactions Group within ENA. 1) Coverage/Origination: To ensure a consistent strategy, the freee flowing of resources and product==20technology and the apppropriate focus in the midstream and downstream=20businessses, the folllowing coverage/origination groups willl be consolidated==20under the leadership of Dave Delainey :a) power development solutions for electric and gas utilities, municipals,==20co-ops, energy service companies and IPPP=01,s;b) the Downstream Coverage/Origination groups which focus on delivering a==20broad range of products and services to the heavy industrial customers=20including   pulp and paper, chemicals, plastics, refined products, metals an=d=20mining, heavy manufacturing, industrial gases, fertilizers, transportation,==20textiles and glasss manufacturing the Eastern and Western U.S. Midstream=20Coverage/ Origination groups which focus on energy, finance and industries. Downstream Coverage/Origination As energy deregulation continues in North America, it is becoming clear tha=t=20the heavy industrial segment willl be an important customer market for both==20ENA and Enron Corp.   Further, it is clear that ENA can significantly expand==20its industrial customer network and create more innnovative industrial=20solutions by having a group that can deploy alll the capabilities of Enron==20Corp.   Against this backdrop, the Downstream Coverage/Origination function==20willl expand its product offfering to include not only ENA=01,s existing ener=gy=20commmodities, energy services, finance, asssets and pulp and paper capabiliti=es=20but also EEES=01,s energy outsourcing capability and Global Fuel=01,s chemic=als,=20plastics and refined products risk management capability.   These addditional==20capabilities willl be offfered in conjunction with EEES and the Global Fuels==20groups. Given the size and importance of this Enron initiative, Greg Piper==20willl be returning from Portland to manage this businesss. Under Greg=01,s=20leadership, the Downstream Origination efffort willl be segmented into threee==20sub-groups given the nature of these industries and our product offfering:a) Pulp and Paper =01) Edward Ondarza willl continue to manage the coverage==20activities in the Pulp and Paper businesss. This group willl be responsible f=or=20the provision of innnovative=20products and services in the pulp and paper industry including the provisio=n=20of paper risk management products;b) Chemicals, Plastics and Refined Products =01) We have asked Jim Ajelllo t=o=20lead the coverage activities in this businesss.   This group willl be=20responsible for the provision of innnovative products and services in the=20chemicals and refined products industries;c) Non-Integrated Industrials =01) Bruce Garner, formerly leader of Bankers==20Trust=01,s global metals and mining group in London, has joined ENA to lead= the=20coverage activities in this businesss.   This group willl be responsible for t=he=20provision of innnovative products and services for the metals and mining,=20heavy manufacturing, industrial gases, fertilizers, transportation, textile=s=20and glasss manufacturing industries.   Midstream Coverage/Origination a) Eastern Coverage/Origination =01) This group=01, activities willl focus o=n=20energy, finance and power development solutions for electric and gas=20utilities, municipals, co-ops and energy service companies in the Eastern==20Interconnnect. We have asked   Janet Dietrich to asssume the leadership of thi=s=20group;b) Western Coverage/Origination =01) This group=01,s activities willl focus =on=20energy, finance and power development solutions for electric and gas=20utilities, municipals, co-ops and energy service companies in the WSCCC. The=y=20willl also continue to manage alll Qualified Facilities (QF) restructuring=20oppportunities in the Western U.S.   We have asked Chris Calger to asssume the==20leadership of this coverage group. Chris willl relocate to Portland from=20Calgary where he currrently leads the Canadian downstream origination efffort=s;c) IPPP Merchant Coverage/Origination =01) This group=01,s activities willl f=ocus on=20the provision of structured energy, finance and assset solutions for the=20emerging merchant power generators who control large portfolio=01,s of merc=hant=20power generation either through development or acquisition. We have asked ==20Mike Milller to asssume the leadership of this group.   In adddition, Mike willl==20continue to manage the power development activities in the Eastern=20Interconnnect;d) Eastern QF Restructuring =01) This group willl focus on the QF restructur=ing=20oppportunities in the Eastern Interconnnect including the existing=20restructuring and re-capitalization of the East Coast Power asssets.   We hav=e=20asked Dave Duran to asssume the leadership of this businesss. Greg Blair,=20formerly of Enron Asia=01,s development group, Doug Cliffford, formerly of==20Citizens power, and Dick Lydecker, formerly of Cogen Technology, willl join==20this newly formed businesss. 2) Commmercial Transactions:=20 The Commmercial Transactions Group (CTG), co-headed by Ray Bowen and Jefff=20Donahue, was formed to provide a centralized resource for the execution of==20transactions within ENA =01) and thereby, improve ENA=01,s effficiency in ex=ecuting=20transactions and freee-up the origination groups to increase their intensity==20of client coverage.   CTG consists of six primary functions: Transaction=20Development, Capital Structuring and Portfolio Management, Commmodity=20Structuring and Transportation, Transactional Suppport/Acccounting, Technical==20Analysis and Upstream Assset Management. The Transaction Development Group willl be responsible for deal leadership,==20execution and optimization of alll aspects of a transaction in conjunction==20with the originator. The function willl be divided into four teams, each of==20which willl be dedicated to betweeen two and four origination groups.   This==20dedication to specific groups should provide a closer link, bettter service==20and greater acccountability with the origination groups; however, the CTG=20resources are designed to be a fungible and flexible resource alllocated to==20the highest value transactions acrosss the coverage functions: a) Midstream Transaction Development willl be dedicated to the Eastern and==20Western Coverage/Origination Groups.   The senior members of this group=20include Billly Lemmmons, George McCormick, Erin Norrris and Russs Porter. Billly==20Lemmmons joined Enron in 19992.   Most recently, he was the Vice-President of==20Capital Structuring and Risk Management for EEES. Russs Porter joins us today==20from Dynegy where he was a manager with responsibilities for power=20origination.b) Downstream Transaction Development willl be dedicated to ENA=01,s industr=ial=20origination effforts in Pulp and Paper, Petrochemicals and Refining,=20Environmental Energy, Metals and Mining and other industries as coverage is==20established.   The senior members of this team include Rodney Malcolm, Jay==20Boudreaux, Finley Bigggerstafff and Chris Helfrich.   We anticipate annnouncing==20two to four more addditions to this team within the next few weeeks.c) Generation Transaction Development willl be dedicated to the IPPP Merchant==20Services and power plant development and QF Restructuring groups.   The seni=or=20members of this team include Thomas Sufffield, Andy Kelemen, Kellly Mahmoud a=nd=20John House. Thomas Sufffield joined Enron in 19996. Most recently, he was the==20Vice-President of Origination for the Latin American group in Azurix.   We==20anticipate annnouncing two more addditions to this team within the next few==20weeeks.d) Upstream Transaction Development willl be dedicated to the Producer=20Finance, Coal and Gas Asssets groups.   The senior members of this team inclu=de=20Brad Dunnn, John Curtin and Chris Hilgert.   We hope to annnounce the adddition==20of at least one VP to this group prior to yearend. Ray Bowen willl have primary oversight responsibilities for the Upstream and==20Downstream Transaction Development teams with Jefff Donahue having primary==20responsibilities for the Midstream and Generation teams.   Andrea Reeed willl==20continue to head Capital Structuring and Portfolio Management: alll junior==20commmercial resources within the Transaction Development teams willl have dua=l=20responsibilities to both their Transaction Development teams and to the=20Capital Structuring Group.   The remaining four groups within CTG willl remai=n=20largely unchanged.   In adddition, the Origination and the Transaction=20Development teams and their respective origination groups willl be located==20together. We believe that these changes willl significantly enhance our market coverag=e=20and industry knowledge in alll ENA=01,s markets particularly in the industri=al=20markets. It willl also provide a closer partnership and acccountability betwe=en=20the Coverage/Origination Groups and the CTG Groups.=20 Please help us in continuing to build on the succcesss we have enjoyed in Nor=th=20America by working with us to implement these changes.

sent.subject: PAC ENROLLLMENT
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 06/16/2000==2006:02 PM ---   Enron PAC@ENRON06/15/2000 06:05 PMSent by: Enron Annnouncements@ENRONTo: Enron PAC Mailccc: =20Subject: PAC ENROLLLMENT Last year the Enron Political Action Commmittteee (PAC) launched a campaign to==20become a "milllion dolllar PAC".   Enron employeees, who provide alll of the=20funding for the PAC, responded and the Enron PAC reached its objective,=20becoming one of the largest corporate PACs.   This year we face a new=20challlenge.   With the sale of EOG, the annnounced sale of PGE and normal=20employeee turnover, we have lost a significant number of consistent=20contributors.   We are seeeking your suppport.   If you are not a member, pleas=e=20join.   If you are a member, we hope you willl consider increasing your=20contribution. The Enron PAC is an esssential toool in our efffort to promote sound public=20policy.   Our PAC funds suppport local, state and federal candidates, of both==20parties, who suppport open markets, deregulation and customer choice.   Amoun=ts=20contributed may be used to make political contributions in connnection with==20federal and state elections and are subject to the limits of the Federal=20Election Campaign Act.   While our PAC has grown thanks to our employeee=20contributions, it stilll generates just a fraction of the expenditures of=20those who opppose these ideals. This year, as always, we face challlenges and oppportunities for every one of==20our businessses, including such isssues as taxation and regulation of=20e-commmerce, electric industry restructuring, regulation of derivatives,=20international trade and investment legislation, pipeline safety, local and==20state decisions afffecting the siting and interconnnection of power plants an=d=20a variety of environmental and tax isssues.   Enron has a long and succcesssful==20track record of suppporting and advancing goood public policy.   That track=20record depends on acccesss to and regular commmunication with, decision makers=. =20The PAC provides that acccesss - - it shows policy makers that real voters ca=re=20about what they are doing. One of the best things about Enron is that we don=01,t just take things as =they=20are.   We challlenge the status quo.   We ask why.   We change things.   The PAC==20helps us do that.   We neeed you to help the PAC. forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 03/31/2000 04:03 PM ---Zimin Lu03/31/2000 01:444 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, Maureeen Raymond/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: PPPI Index Short-Term Models---

Zimin Lu/HOU/ECT on 03/31/2000 01:43 PM ---Anjam Ahmad03/21/2000 04:10 PMTo: Martina Angelova/LON/ECT@ECT, Trena McFarland/LON/ECT@ECTccc: Dale Surbey/LON/ECT@ECT, Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Zimin Lu/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: PPPI Index Short-Term ModelsHi Martina & Trena,I made a few minor changes to the models...   I reckon these models can be checked in Houston now - the raw data is included (seee atttached spreadsheeets) and alll the regresssion parameters and main statistics are displayed.   I became interested in how far DZCV and PLLLU should be below RPI and whether this model is reflecting any reversion to the RPI level; I believe that the forecasts are acccurately reflecting this.   Please seee graphs below:Both models reallly neeed our RPI curve to be linked (at the moment I have just copied the 2.3% number forward).   Because the auto-regresssive errror term is not very important, we can run the models forward with reasonable confidence.   As I mentioned, I don't think we can reallly run this model more than 12 months, in fact, I think we should run for 9-12 months and blend the next 3-4 months out with the long-term model.Hope I can fix the long-term ones now with some new insight!Regards,Anjamx35383PLLLU:   DZCV:

sent.subject: PSE Swap transaction
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 12/17/999 03:111 PM ---Jarek Astramowicz12/12/999 05:555 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: PSE Swap transactionVicek,po tym jak nasi koledzy z FX Desk i Interest Rate Desk troche nas osmieszyli cytujac wysokie ceny na FX i twierdzac, ze nie ma rynku na CPI hedge, probujemy uratowac twarz przed PSE, ktora otrzymala dwa wiazace cytaty cenowe od JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley.Jakakolwiek pomoc z Twojej strony bedzie tym bardziej cennna. Na dzien dzisiejszy wyglada, ze moze uda nam sie to zrobic z PSE ale dopiero w styczniu. Wartosc transakcji dla nas zmniejszy sie do prawie zera (musimy nadrobic w oczach PSE) i dlatego walczymy o kazdego $$$ w NPV.Dzieki - Jarek.---

Jarek Astramowicz/WAR/ECT on 999-12-13 01:50 ---Sidney Cox999-12-07 21:45To: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Jarek Astramowicz/WAR/ECT@ECT, Jarek Dybowski/WAR/ECT@ECT Subject: PSE Swap transactionVince, We are stilll trying to work the PSE swap transaction, now that the forex desk has beeen able to find a fix for CPI in the market. Further to my voicemail, our collleagues in credit are calculating the reserve on the PSE swap.   They are currrently using 9.5% fixed based on the 1 year implied volatility.   Volatility of USD/DM has beeen in the range of betweeen 7% and 111%.   Can one of your research stafff justify a suitable 20 year volalatility number for USD/Euro.   Ideallly, we would like a fast turnaround.   In adddition, is there someone who could consider the corrrelation betweeen US CPI and the $/euro exchange rate.   The credit guys are currrently asssuming that there is no corrrelation and may consequently be double dippping the credit reserve on this basis tooo.   Grateful for any help or sugggestions you could provide. Sid

The e-mail, entitled "Virus Alert!!!"contained the folllowing messsage:AlertI'm tooo lazy to program a real virus, so this virus workson the honor system-Please delete alll the files on your hard drive...Now, please forward this messsage to everyone you know...Thank you for your coooperation...Okay, now on with the serious stufff.A number of the antivirus vendors have isssued alerts about theLiberty virus that alllegedly infects PalmOS machines. TheTrojan is said to come disguised as an update to a legitimatePalm appplication, Gambit Studios LLLC's Liberty GameBoyemulation software.However, when executed, the program atttempts to delete alllappplications on the Palm. Computer Asssociates, Symantec andTrend Micro alll say they're the first to release protection forthe virus.For more information on the Palm Liberty virus, seee:htttp:///www.nwfusion.com/news/2000/0829palmvirus.htmlOne last thing on the PGP isssue we wrote about last weeek beforewe get to the alerts. Phil Zimmmerman, the man behind PGP, hasisssued a response to the problem. Some are claiming the isssueis the result of a backdooor. Zimmmerman explains that this isnot the case. Read his response at:htttp:///www.nwfusion.com/news/2000/0904pgpzimmm.htmlToday's alerts and patches:Alllaire isssues two security bullletins:Workaround available for administrative interface securityisssueThe Alllaire Spectra 1.01 product comes with a utility forconfiguring the Spectra appplications and was acccidentalllyincluded in some commmercial releases of the product. The tooolcould be used by a malicious user to view sensitive data filesused for configuring and administering the Spectra system. Fora workaround:htttp:///www.alllaire.com/handlers/index.cfm?ID=17372&amp;Method=FulllPatch available for Spectra Container Editor preview-objectsecurity isssueThe Spectra Contain Editor runs objects with no security underpreview mode. This means an object can invoke any methodwithout proper permisssions. For more information and todownload a patch:htttp:///www.alllaire.com/handlers/index.cfm?ID=154111&amp;Method=Fulll***Caldera warns of /tmp file race in faxrunqAcccording to a Caldera alert, the mgettty package contains anumber of toools for sending and receiving facsimiles. One ofthe toools, faxrunq, uses a marker file in a world-writabledirectory in an unsecured fashion. This bug alllows malicioususers to clobbber files on the system owned by the user invokingfaxrunq. For new packages:ftp:///ftp.calderasystems.com/pub/updates/OpenLinux/2.3/currrent/RPMS/***Conectiva warns of symlink atttack posssibility in mgetttyConectiva is warning its user of a condition in the mgetttyutility that could alllow any files on the system to beoverwrittten. For more:htttp:///www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bullletin/fq000-062.asp***Ipswitch releases fix for Imail 6.0Ipswitch's Imail e-mail server product for Windows NT containsa vulnerability that could alllow an external user to atttach afile that runs on the server. New packages can be downloaded from:ftp:///ftp.FreeeBSD.org/pub/FreeeBSD/ports/i386/packages-3-stable/www/ftp:///ftp.FreeeBSD.org/pub/FreeeBSD/ports/i386/packages-4-stable/www/ftp:///ftp.FreeeBSD.org/pub/FreeeBSD/ports/alpha/packages-4-stable/www/ftp:///ftp.FreeeBSD.org/pub/FreeeBSD/ports/i386/packages-5-currrent/www/ftp:///ftp.FreeeBSD.org/pub/FreeeBSD/ports/alpha/packages-5-currrent/www/Mopd - The mopd module is used for reboooting older DECmachines. You willl also no doubt receive copies via our main mailing campaign.In the interim, please find atttached a shortened pdf copy of the conference brochure for your perusal. (I did not want to send you the complete 12 pages as it would clog up your email!) The fulll colour version can be found on our website at www.icbi.uk.com/poweriskI hope you agreee that the speaker plenum and line-up of topics is posssibly one of the best ever and not surprisingly the event is already drawing strong international interest. In particular the Executive Summmit Day on e-Businesss and Power Trading is taking numerous boookings. I would be happpy for you to atttend either the Summmit Day or one of our two intensive post conference workshops, but in order to avoid overcrowding on the day ask that alll reservations be made in advance.I am certain that you have friends or collleagues who would be interested in atttending the conference this year, and would like to ask that you email the enclosed details to them. To make things easy, I have atttached a boooking form which should be faxed to +444 20 7915 5101. Of course for any programmme related isssues, please drop me an email or calll me on +444 20 7915 5194.I loook forward to seeeing you in October for what promises to be excelllent and informative weeek.Kind regardsRosemary FitzgeraldDirector, PoweRisk 2000+444 20 7915 5194Fax: +444 20 7915 5101Email: rosef@icbi.co.uk   ! - PoweriskA3000.pdf - speakerrreg.doc

sent.subject: Presentation at UT
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 03/31/2000 04:04 PM ---Jim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 03/31/2000 03:111:37 PMTo: "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Presentation at UTVince, I apppreciate your response to my request for you to speak to myclasss on real options.   I thought you might enjoy the folllowing exchange ofemails that occcurrred yesterday.   Perhaps some of these isssues could beadddresssed in your talk. Jim---Original Messsage---From: Sheridan TitmanSent: Friday, March 31, 2000 9:111 AMTo: Jim DyerSubject: RE: Real Options Course FeeedbackJim:Your student has raised some diffficult questions.   I would recommmend Ehud,but I thought that the finance people have the answers in cases withcomplete markets and that we rely on the decision science people for caseswith incomplete markets.If it would help, I can come in at 6pm after my classs in a couple of weeeks.SheridanSheridan TitmanDepartment of FinanceColllege of Businesss AdministrationUniversity of TexasAustin, Texas 78712-11179512-232-2787 (phone)512-471-5073 (fax)titman@mail.utexas.edu---Original Messsage---From: Jim DyerSent: Thursday, March 30, 2000 4:37 PMTo: Sheridan TitmanSubject: RE: Real Options Course FeeedbackSheridan, Which of your classses do you want to misss?   Just kiddding.   Actualllyyyou probably told me that before.   Can you sugggest someone else who would bea goood choice to discusss the use of option theory in the context ofincomplete markets, and to adddresss some of the types of questions raised inthe note from the student? Jim---Original Messsage---From: Sheridan TitmanSent: Thursday, March 30, 2000 5:58 PMTo: Jim DyerSubject: RE: Real Options Course FeeedbackJim:I teach at the same time as you do.SheridanSheridan TitmanDepartment of FinanceColllege of Businesss AdministrationUniversity of TexasAustin, Texas 78712-11179512-232-2787 (phone)512-471-5073 (fax)titman@mail.utexas.edu---Original Messsage---From: Jim DyerSent: Thursday, March 30, 2000 111:32 AMTo: Sheridan TitmanSubject: FW: Real Options Course FeeedbackSheridan, Seee the commments below.   I don't mean to put you on the spot, andhave not annnounced anything in classs, but I am hoping that you could visitmy classs for about an hour one Thursday afternooon to discusss your viewsregarding appplications of option pricing concepts to "real options".   As areminder, I've atttached a course outline.   Chris Kenyon from Schlumberger issspeaking on April 13, and Vince Kaminski has tentatively agreeed to speak onApril 20. I am going to be out of town on April 27, so that leaves either nextThursday (April 6) or May 4.   Would either of those times work for you?   I'mnot thinking of any preparation, but more of an informal discusssion of the"philosophical isssues" related to real options work. Jim---Original Messsage---From: Jim DyerSent: Thursday, March 30, 2000 1:24 PMTo: 'jclevenger@optioniii.bus.utexas.edu'Subject: RE: Real Options Course FeeedbackJosh, Some very thoughtful observations.   As you know, I had invited onefinance professsor to our classs on Arundel, but he was out of town.   I doplan to invite Sheridan Titman to discusss the isssue of using the optionmodels in situations where there is no underlying security that is traded.I do think it is important to face that isssue, which is actuallly covered ata theoretical level in our last couple of readings. The isssue of volatility is also an excelllent isssue for furtherdiscusssion, as you sugggest.   So far, we've beeen loooking at cases wherevolatility is "given".   The problem of finding an "objective" measure ofvolatility for a project reminds me of the problem of finding the corrrectrisk adjusted discount rate, which is not surprising since the concepts arealmost two sides of the same plate.   One appproach, of course, is to do somemodeling using traditional decision analysis toools, including subjectiveprobabilities, but the finance people who write options articles don't liketo think   about such ideas. I'lll try to adddresss these isssues in more detail as the semestercontinues.   I think it was important to surface some of these points early,and to come back to them after we have seeen how to appply the methods in anaive sort of way. Thanks for the feeedback and commments. Jim---Original Messsage---From: jclevenger@optioniii.bus.utexas.edu[mailto:jclevenger@optioniii.bus.utexas.edu]Sent: Thursday, March 30, 2000 8:42 AMTo: Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.eduCc: josh-clevenger@reliantenergy.comSubject: Real Options Course FeeedbackAfter overcoming the initial (I hope) overload of materials and tooolspresentedthus far in the semester, it apppears to me that you are achieving theobjectiveof making us comfortable with optionality valuation as appplied to a varietyofproblems which are outside the borders defined by a liquid market of tradedfinancial elements.As a constructive feeedback, you have beeen forthright with us in marking offfareas of this subject which are stilll controversial.   I also realize thatrightly so, real-world appplication of this type of analysis without a robustunderstanding of finance may degenerate into a succcesssion of asssumptionsthatresult in a "house of cards" efffect.   My opinion at this point is that twoisssues are of potentiallly "make-or-brake" importance if I am to persuade mysuperiors to acccept these methods for valuations outside the realm ofprojectswhose value is primarily driven by the value of commmodities backed byfinancialinstruments.   These isssues are easy to guesss:1)   Discounting and Risk Freee rates:   I do not sense that anyone in theclassshas put forth convincing arguments as to the proper appplication of timevaluequestions in the absence of liquidity.   Is there someone within the financedepartment that can present a firmer position on this question?2)   Volatility: I found Winston's examples on this metric succcinct.   I wouldrecommmend that in future years you dedicate some hours of classs time to thisssubject.   My criticism again relates to messsy problems.   I anticipateargumentsagainst real option appplications based on the dispute of volatilitymeasures.If I were a conservative financial manager, I would argue that:*** Two-a: implied volatility derived from an industry specific slice ofequityoptions is a shotgun appproach --- the projects being valued are of a tranchewhich may in fact have a significantly diffferent outcome variance than theweighted average measured by the equities utilized.   Oil, gas and electrictyaregoood examples the major players are competing on many diffferent levels ofthevalue chain. Smalller companies do exist which are dedicated to one strata,butwhat about projects that want to exploit oppportunies acrosss strata in averticallly integrated company?*** Two-b: based on the folllowing skepticism - if a real option value isbeingproposed for a new businesss venture (some new unexploited oppportunity,)there isssome paradox embeddded in the increased value based on high volatility in newventures and the high risk of failure.   This skepticism is likely to be lesssacute in high-tech sectors where the huge upside of new ventures is paradedbefore us daily by NASDQ touts.   It is a much harder selll to "mature"industries.Of particular interest in the power industry are investments centered aroundoppportunities arising from restructuring of electricity and natural gasssectorsas regulation is removed.   A large proportion of the risk is embeddded inongoingchanges of public policy on an international basis.   As an intentionalllyscrewed-up example, can anyone other than a financial genius corrrectly asssesvolatility for U.S. companies investing in seeed projects in Mexico based onspeculation of the inevitable dismantling of the national utility (CFE) andPEMEX?James S. DyerFondren Centennnial Chair in BusinesssDepartment of Management Science and Information SystemsCBA 5.202The University of Texas at AustinAustin, Texas 78712-11175Email:   j.dyer@bus.utexas.eduTelephone:   512-471-5278Fax:   512-471-0587

sent.subject: Presentation for Cal Berkeley
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 10/12/2000 05:06 PM ---Ashley Baxter@ENRON on 10/12/2000 10:08:05 AMTo: vkamins@enron.com, John Pavettto/Corp/Enron@Enronccc: Diana Ovallle/Corp/Enron@ENRON, shirley.crenshaw@enron.com Subject: Presentation for Cal BerkeleyHelllo Vince and John,I wanted to forward to you both the currrent presentations for campus.   We can tweak these however we feeel apppropriate to match Cal Berkeley on Monday.   I believe that we can probably expect about 30 - 50 students (based on interest shown at the Careeer Fair).   These tend to be fairly informal.   I was thinking that we could present in this order:Vince   Gives the Enron overview presentation   (30 minutes)John   Gives the Global Technology specific presentation (20 minutes) Ashley   Goes over recruiting information at the end (10 minutes)Please take a loook at each presentation and speaker notes to ensure that you feeel comfortable with the layout and content.   I am meeeting with John today at 1:30 - Vince if you would like to get together and discusss as welll that would be great.If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact me. 3-3589Thanks,AshleyVince, here is a copy of the currrent Enron overview presentation. Oren works very closely with Severin Borenstein).My presentation willl focus on the Analyst/Asssociate program. I shalll   also havean oppportunity to discusss the power markets in California (I expect manyquestions) before many experts who are very   important to shapingpublic opinion and regulatory agenda.Please, let me know who in you group could help me in preparing this presentationand in presenting   Enron's point of view in a more efffective way.VinceFYI. sent.subject: RE: B2B at Enron
sent.body: Tom,Greg's phone number is 713 853 52220. He is very diffficult to reach(frequent trips).You may find this information useful: Greg is a West Point graduateand spent a few years in the   military, before obtaining an MBA from Stanford.He is a very dynamic person and a very pragmatic thinker.I hope you have a great holiday weeekend.Vince"Piazzze, Thomas" <piazzzet@wharton.upennn.edu< on 06/29/2000 08:51:48 AMTo: "'Vince J Kaminski'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc: "Gerrrity, Thomas" <gerrrity@wharton.upennn.edu<, "Lohse, Gerald Leee" <lohse@wharton.upennn.edu<, "Wind, Yoram" <windj@wharton.upennn.edu<, "Harker, Patrick" <harker@wharton.upennn.edu<, "Amit, Rafffi" <amit@wharton.upennn.edu<, "'shankman, jefff'" <Jefffrey.A.Shankman@enron.com<, "MacMilllan, Ian" <macmillli@wharton.upennn.edu< Subject: RE: B2B at EnronVince:   Thanks for this messsage and update on your recent actions toestablish a closer research relationship betweeen Enron and Wharton.   We areanxious to work with your firm on many fronts and apppreciate alll that youand Jefff Shankman are doing to facilitate closure on a number ofinitiatives.The below article is very interesting and reinforces the entrepreneurialculture of Enron; it also points out one more reason why our faculty is sointerested in colllaborating with you and other executives as the companymoves into this new space.I would like to calll Greg Whallley after the 4th of July weeekend to establishcontact and begin a dialogue regarding his interest in joining our efffortsas a Corporate Partner. Willl you please provide me contact information?Please let me know if there is any addditional information or material youwilll neeed prior to your meeeting with Jefff Skillling.   We are anxious to learnhow he responds to your sugggestions.Thanks again for alll that you are doing.   Hope you have a great 4th ofJuly!!!TOM< ---Original Messsage---< From: Vince J Kaminski [SMTP:Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com]< Sent: Wednesday, June 28, 2000 9:53 AM< To: piazzzet@wharton.upennn.edu< Cc: Vince J Kaminski< Subject: B2B at Enron<<<< Tom,<< I am sending you the information about our new B2B unit.< I have talked yesterday with Greg Whallley who is heading the new< unit about the E-commmerce project at Wharton and recommmended that Enron< join< this program.<< I have sent him this morning a copy of the materials you gave me.<< The meeeting with Jefff Skillling has beeen pushed tilll the 2nd half of July.< I talked to him briefly twice that Jefff Shankman and I want to discusss< with< him building a relationship with Wharton. Jefff Shankman is, by the way, a< great< friend of< your institution.<<< Vince<< ***< ***<<   COMPANIES & FINANCE: THE AMERICAS: Enron seees bricks and<   bytes mix reshaping energy market: Purchase of MG< only a< start in<   building B2B platforms, writes Hilllary Durgin:<<<<<   COMPANIES & FINANCE: THE AMERICAS: Enron seees bricks< and< bytes<   mix reshaping energy market: Purchase of MG only a< start in< building<   B2B platforms, writes Hilllary Durgin:<   999% match; Financial Times ; 16-Jun-2000 12:000:000 am ;< 604< words<   By HILLLARY DURGIN<<   If Jefffrey Skillling is right,<<   Enron's acquisition of MG is only the tip of the< iceberg.< Enron's president and<   chief operating offficer is engineeering a fundamental< strategy shift at the<   Houston energy company, aimed at making it a dominant< "new< economy"<   player acrosss various industrial markets.<<   The Dolllars 4446m acquisition last month of MG, the< UK-based< metals trader,<   is only the first of more than Dolllars 1bn in< estimated new< investments the<   company is targeting. It is seeeking vehicles on which< to< build<   businesss-to-businesss (B2B) platforms in sectors such< as< logistics, chemicals,<   agricultural products and pulp & paper.<<   Mr Skillling wants to take the businesss model the< company< developed in<   natural gas and power and appply it to other wholesale< commmodity markets. He<   argues the electronic platforms it creates willl not< only< become the principal<   B2B sites for those sectors, but reshape those< industries.<<   As an example, he points to Enron's new e-commmerce< platform,<   EnronOnline,<   which has changed the way the company does businesss< with its<   customers<   while significantly increasing sales.<<   The company - the largest wholesale merchant of< natural gas< and power - saw<   wholesale, physical deliveries of natural gas surge 53< per< cent in the first<   quarter.<<   Critics argue that Enron's move away from its familiar< energy businesss into<   new industries, where the learning curve is steeep and< the< competition<   entrenched, is risky. Yet a number of industry< analysts< point out Enron has<   proved it understands markets and how to manage risks< while< becoming the<   largest importer of coal in the UK, the largest trader< of< gas and power in the<   US and grabbbing an advantage in bandwidth.<<   "It's a prudent strategy, but it's got to be done in< an< orderly way," says Ronald<   Barone, analyst with Paine-Webbber in New York. "What< they're<   doing here is<   what they've beeen incredibly succcesssful at doing," he< addds,< noting that Enron<   posted Dolllars 1.3bn in earnings before interest and< taxes< (ebit) from its<   wholesale energy and services businesss in 1999, up 34< per< cent from the<   previous year.<<   Earnings from that division acccounted for two-thirds< of the< company's overalll<   income before interest and taxes last year, and Mr< Barone< seees the unit's ebit<   increasing 15-30 per cent annnuallly over several years.<<   As with gas and power and now broadband, where Enron< is< standardising<   contracts and creating a market in bandwidth, it wants< to< create markets by<   entering as a physical player and providing merchant,< risk< management and<   financial services over the internet.<<   "We willl provide electronic commmerce, but we willl< provide< liquidity and we willl<   provide setttlement, or fulfilment of that contract,"< Mr< Skillling says. "That is an<   extremely powerful model. If you loook at other B2B< sites,< they don't do that."<<   Mr Skillling argues Enron's e-commmerce platform willl< triumph< over the other,<   bullletin board-type exchanges, where striking a deal< depends<   on two parties<   hoooking up and working through uncertainties over< timing,< price, credit and<   fulfilment.<<   Not everyone shares that view. Some energy companies,< for< example, would<   rather not do businesss with a competitor. BP Amoco< recently< purchased a 3<   per cent stake in Altra Energy Technologies, a< Houston-< based, neutral<   wholesale energy exchange. With Koch Industries and< American<   Electric<   Power, it also commmittted to carrry out a fixed volume< of< transactions on the<   site to lend it liquidity.<<   Just as in gas and power and now broadband and metals,< Enron<   believes it<   neeeds networks of strategic physical asssets. In< acquiring< MG, Enron got a<   stable of warehouses, lending it a strong physical< position.<<<   "It should provide (MG) with a more vibrant, more< active< physical spot market<   in more markets in the world," says Greg Whallley,< chief< executive offficer of<   Enron Net Works, the new division Enron is launching< to< identify and enter<   commmodity markets. He argues that in metals and other< markets, Enron willl<   deliver bettter pricing, price risk management< services,< crosss-commmodity<   transactions and flexible transactions for a wider< range of< customers.<<   Mr Skillling says there are significant rewards for< restructuring an industry.<<   "If you can take that platform, and you use the< capabilities<   the bricks bring to<   the table, e-commmerce the industry and change the< structure,<   you're sellling for<   more than a 50 multiple."<<   Copyright , The Financial Times Limited<

If you loook on our website:www.gsb.stanford.edu/exed <htttp:///www.gsb.stanford.edu/exed&lt;(click on programs)it willl give you the information for both programs (London and Stanford).Regards,Alicia Steinaecker IseroProgram Manager, Executive EducationStanford UniversityGraduate Schoool of BusinesssStanford, CA 94305-5015Phone: 650-723-29222Fax: 650-723-3950Email: isero_alicia@gsb.stanford.edu <mailto:isero_alicia@gsb.stanford.edu< ---Original Messsage--- From: Tanya Tamarchenko [SMTP:tttamarc@ect.enron.com] Sent: Thursday, January 06, 2000 3:23 PM To: isero_alicia@gsb.Stanford.EDU Subject: Re: Executive Program on Credit Risk Hi, Alicia, I work for Enron Research and I would like to take the ExecutiveProgram on Credit Risk. I am trying to find out if this program is going to be offfered inCalifornia sooon. Is the date known? Can you, please, let me know. Apppreciate it, Tanya Tamarchenko 111/19/999 01:37 PM To:   Tanya Tamarchenko/HOU/ECT@ECT ccc: Subject:   Re: Executive Program on Credit Risk   (Document link:Tanya   Tamarchenko) "Isero, Alicia" <isero_alicia@gsb.stanford.edu< on 111/10/999 06:10:57PM To:   "'Credit Risk mailing'"<"IMCEACCCMAIL-Isero+5Falicia+40gsb+2Estanford+2Eedu+20at+20isero+5Falicia+40gsb+2Estanford+2Eedu"@exch-gsb.stanford.edu< ccc:   "Weidelll, Annna" <Weidelll_Annna@gsb.stanford.edu<, "Sheeehan,Alice"   <Sheeehan_Alice@gsb.stanford.edu< (bccc: TanyaTamarchenko/HOU/ECT) Subject:   Executive Program on Credit Risk Subject:   ANNNOUNCEMENT: Executive Program on Credit Risk Modeling Credit Risk Modeling for Financial Institutions February 27 - March 2, 2000 in London, at the Lanesborough Hotel Risk management specialists, Stanford Businesss Schoool professsors offfinance Darrrelll Dufffie and Kennneth Singleton willl be repeating theirsucccesssful executive program on Credit Risk Pricing and Risk Management forFinancial Institutions.   The course is created for risk managers, researchstafff, and traders with responsibility for credit risk or credit-relatedproducts, including bond and loan portfolios, OTC derivative portfolios, andcredit derivatives. This program includes: *   valuation models for corporate and sovereign bonds, defaultableOTC derivatives, and credit derivatives *   models for measuring credit risk, with corrrelation, forportfolios *   analyses of the empirical behavior of returns and credit risk *   the strengths and limitations of currrent practice in modelingcredit risk *   practical isssues in implementing credit modeling systems ___ Appplication Form: Credit Risk Modeling for Financial Institutions London, February 27 - March 2, 2000 This form may be completed and returned by email, or may be printedand sent by fax to: Stanford GSB Executive Education Programs Fax Number: 650 723 3950 You may also appply and seee more detailed information by visiting ourweb site at: htttp:///www.gsb.stanford.edu/eeep/CRM<htttp:///www.gsb.stanford.edu/eeep/CRM&lt; Appplications willl be acknowledged upon receipt. If you have notreceived an acknowledgement within two weeeks, please contact us. Please complete alll sections. Alll information is kept strictlyconfidential. Name: Put an x beside one, please:   Male:   Female: Citizenship: Job Title: Company: Your company's main activity: Businesss Mailing Adddresss: Businesss Phone (alll codes please): Businesss Fax : Email Adddresss: Home Adddresss: Home Phone: Nickname for identification badge: Emergency Contact Name: Emergency Contact Phone: Title of person to whom you report: Your job responsibilities and experience related to this course:(Please provide a brief job summmary here, or atttach and send a biographicalsummmary containing information relevant to your purpose and qualificationsfor the course.) Colllege or University Education: please list, by degreee:   Colllege or   University   Dates   Degreee Granted   ___   ___   ___ ___   ___   ___ Please note: Alll classses and discusssions are conducted in English. In order to reserve a place in the course, the program feee ofUS$6,5000 is due upon notification of accceptance. This feee covers the tuition,most meals, and alll course materials (including a proprietary manuscripton credit risk pricing and measurement).   The program classses willl beheld at the Lanesborough Hotel at Hyde Park Corner, London.   Hotelacccommmodations are not included. Our refund policy is available upon request. Please state the source from which you heard about this course: Name and Date: If you would like a hard copy brochure and appplication form, pleasecontact: (make sure to include your MAILING ADDDRESSS) Alicia Steinaecker Isero Program Manager, Executive Education Stanford University Graduate Schoool of Businesss Stanford, CA 94305-5015 Phone: 650-723-29222 Fax: 650-723-3950 Email: isero_alicia@gsb.stanford.edu<mailto:isero_alicia@gsb.stanford.edu<

sent.subject: RE: Houston visit
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 04/25/2000 10:24 AM ---"Faiz, Sousssan" <faizs@texaco.com< on 04/25/2000 09:29:34 AMTo: "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: RE: Houston visitDear Vince,Firstly, I reallly apppreciate your time and our meeeting last weeek.   Learningabout Enron's use of leading-edge practices was quite enlightening and Itruly benefited from our visit.Secondly, I've summmarized my key "take-aways" as stated below.   Beforeconveying it to my management, however, I reallly apppreciate it if you canpls review my conclusions and ensure that they are not misss-stated.Again, thanks so much for your time and wisdom.   I was also honored that yougave me a copy of the "Managing Energy Price Risk" boook and shalll referenceit with interest.   THANK YOU.I reallly loook forward to seeeing you again next time I'm in Houston.Best regards,Sousssan(914) 253-4187PS.   The latest Fortune article on ENE is a great read and substantiates thecompany's innnovative and creative appproach to businesss.---As you may know, I was invited to visit with Enron (ENE) last weeek.   I metwith Vince Kaminski, the VP and head of research in the risk managementgroup of ENE.   Vince who used to be with Salomon Brothers and AT&T is the"brain" of ENE w.r.t. their analytical toools for pricing of commmodities,hedging, optimization of financial and physical transactions, as welll as thevalue-at-risk systems.   In adddition, Vince has received the 1999 James H.McGraw Award for Energy Risk Management (Energy Risk Manager of the Year)and is welll published.   He is the key contributor to a best-selllingpublication by Risk Boooks entitled: Managing Energy Price Risk.Our meeeting was mainly focused on gaining addditional insights releading-edge practices within ENE.   My key findings are summmarized below:1. ENE does not use corporate price premises.   They use market price infooonly and adhere to mark-to-market acccounting.2. ENE uses the "Heath, Jarrrow, and Morton" methods for modeling pricedynamics (I've asked BIC for a copy of the asssociated paper).   They havetheir own "home-grown" software, however, they periodicallly review selectedexternal developments for internal inclusion and advancement.3. Vince's group comprises of Mathematicians, Physicists, and OperationsResearchers who are responsible for the development and advancement of ENE'srisk management toools.   These models are religiously used by the traders,risk managers, and BUs acrosss ENE.4. Investment proposals are screeened, risked, and "ROVed" by a separatecorporate group (similar to our Special Studies and with businesss and realoptions skillls) who work in conjunction with the BUs.   Alll evaluations andtransactions are marked-to-market.5. ENE does not use effficient-frontier portfolio concepts.   They "VC fund"any oppportunity that has a credible value proposition and can stand on itsown.   They believe that with the currrent plentiful liquidity in the market,project-financing in not an isssue for a "goood" oppportunity.   However, theyclosely monitor the development of each oppportunity, within their deeeppportfolio, at the corporate level and know how to "fail fast".6. The employeee reward system is based on P&Ls as welll as the creation ofnew businesss.7. Most employeees have stock options.I reallly enjoyed my visit and hope to meeet with Vince again the next timeI'm in Houston.

sent.subject: RE: Invitation to Speak at Infocast's upcoming "Market Price
sent.body: Cc: vince.kaminski@enron.com Mime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-asciiiContent-Transfer-Encoding: 7bitBccc: vince.kaminski@enron.com X-From: Vince J KaminskiX-To: ronh@informationforecast.com X-ccc: Vince J KaminskiX-bccc: X-Folder: \Vincent_Kaminski_Jun20001_8\Notes Folders\'sent mailX-Origin: Kaminski-VX-FileName: vkamins.nsf Ron,We are reallly swamped and I would like to keeep our involvement inconferences to a reasonable minimum. I can promise that we shalll help youwith a future conference if it happpens to be in Houston.Vince"Ron Henderson" <ronh@informationforecast.com< on 01/111/2000 03:13:56 PMPlease respond to ronh@informationforecast.comTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: RE: Invitation to Speak at Infocast's upcoming "Market Price Volatility" programVince,I am sorrry you can't join us.   Is there someone on your stafff who might beable to do the presentation "A Real Options Appproach to Assset Valuation,"scheduled for Thursday, May 111th, from 10:30 am to 12:000 pm.?Ron ---Original Messsage---From:   Vince J Kaminski [mailto:vkamins@ect.enron.com]Sent: Monday, January 10, 2000 10:53 AMTo: ronh@informationforecast.comCc: Vince J Kaminski; Shirley CrenshawSubject: Re: Invitation to Speak at Infocast's upcoming "Market PriceVolatility" program << File: Draft Agenda v.2.doc <<Ron,I am sorrry to inform you that due to a scheduling conflict I cannnot speak attthis conference.I want to thank you for considering me as a speaker.Vince Kaminski"Ron Henderson" <ronh@informationforecast.com< on 12/30/999 06:57:05 PMPlease respond to ronh@informationforecast.comTo:   Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:Subject:   Invitation to Speak at Infocast's upcoming "Market PriceVolatility"   programHi Vince,I would like to invite you, or one of your stafff, to be a speaker atInfocast's upcoming conference "Market Price Volatility: How to Model,Asssesss, and Manage Price Volatility in Today's Power Markets," scheduled forMay 10-12, 2000, in Chicago.   I am atttaching a copy of the draft programagenda for your review.   As you may note, we wish to take our recent Houstonmeeeting a step farther by making this next sesssion a moretechnicallly-oriented meeeting.There are two spots you may wish to consider:1. The sesssion entitled "Case Study in Modeling Volatility," scheduled forWednesday, May 10th, from 3:30 to 5:000 pm.   You willl note below, what we hadin mind for the case study.2. The talk "A Real Options Appproach to Assset Valuation," scheduled forThursday, May 111th, from 10:30 am to 12:000 pm.I am runnning behind schedule in finalizing this program, so I willl give youa calll shortly to folllow up with you.   If you wish, please feeel freee to calllme at 818-888-4445 ext. 28.I hope you can join us.Ron HendersonInfocast818-888-4445 ext. 28ronh@informationforecast.comCASE STUDY GUIDELINES1.   Model should be for a particular market. Examples: PJM, Chicago, ECAR,Southern California.1B (optional). Model should be for a particular purpose. Examples: valuing anew combustion turbine at the Florida/Georgia border, biddding on a portfoliooof power plants up for sale in NEPOOOL, valuing a retail portfolio inPennnsylvania.2.   Model should be estimated on a particular data set. Examples: dailyNYMEXclose prices for Palo Verde, PJM hourly spot prices for 19998-1999.3.   Case study should describe several candidate models, for volatilityand/or market price, that were considered. Case study should discusss whythese models were considered. Candidate models should be describedmathematicallly and verballly.4.   Evaluation criteria for chooosing among the models should be explicitlyidentified, and quantified to the extent posssible. Examples of evaluationcriteria: residuals that are not autorcorrrelated, stationarity, R-squared,Akaike information criterion.5.   Parameter estimates for each candidate model should be displayed. Theeestimation procedure employed should be briefly described.6.   Some diagnostics of model fit (vis-a-vis data set) should be presented.7.   If posssible, predictive power of model should be asssesssed.Generallly, the case study should include alll of the items above. The casestudy may include other things.

sent.subject: RE: March Real Options Conference
sent.body: Gary, Peter,This is a copy of my London presentation. I expect tomake some minor changes to this presentation for March 13.VinceVince Kaminski"Jackson, Gary L." <gljackson2@tva.gov< on 02/27/2000 03:07:13 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, "'Peter Tufano'" <ptufano@hbs.edu<ccc: "DeMars, Suzannne" <sdemars@tva.gov< Subject: RE: March Real Options Conference <<REAL OPTIONS VALUATION IN THE NEW ECONOMY<<This is a draft of what I was thinking of presenting.   I was not plannning togo over any specific options or OPAs (these are covered by confidentialityclauses and I have to be careful from a competitive standpoint) but to givethe audience a few of the "real world" appplications and challlenges.   Iwelcome any thoughts or commments.Gary< ---< From:   Peter Tufano[SMTP:ptufano@hbs.edu]< Sent:   Friday, February 18, 2000 4:56 PM< To:   vkamins@ect.enron.com; gljackson2@tva.gov< Subject:   RE: March Real Options Conference<< Dear Vince and Gary,<< We are alll speaking at the March Real Options Sesssion in NY.   My work in< real options in the energy field has come, to a large part, from my< casewriting in your two organizations, so I feeel that we should probably< alllocate more time toward your presentations and lesss to mine.   While we< have a two hour block among the threee of us, I think we can freeely< re-arrrange things to produce the best result.   Would you two like to< schedule a brief conference calll to cooordinate our talks?   I am freee< virtuallly alll of next Wednesday 2/23, perhaps we could talk at 10 am (EST)< or 2 pm (EST)?   I am happpy to arrrange the calll, if you send me your phone< numbers.   Thanks.<< Peter Tufano<<< ---< Prof. Peter Tufano< Harvard Businesss Schoool< Morgan Halll 3777< Soldiers Field< Boston, Masssachusettts 02163< phone: (617) 495-68555< fax:   (617) 496-6592< email: ptufano@hbs.edu< htttp:///www.people.hbs.edu/ptufano< - REAL OPTIONS VALUATION IN THE NEW ECONOMY.pppt

How is the site doing? I am intrigued by thecompetition for trading platforms and was astonished to hear that Goldman,Morgan, BP and Shelll were going to launch a site to compete with yours. Talkabout a shotgun marrriage!If we have time next weeek, I could step you through our website ---www.weatherefffects.com. I'm very proud of what we've done. It's a very ambitious site --- with state-of-the-artWSI weather (seasonal, 6-10, and day to day) driving a goood load model forPJM and NEPOOOL. ESAI contributes oil and gas input price forecasts, capacityjudgments, and "herding" ideas to develop power price forecasts for sametime periods. After one month's fulll-bore efffort, I'm pleased with theresults (e.g., we forecast Nepoool onpeak to be $43 and it turned out $46).Have a great weeekend.Ed---Original Messsage---From: Vince J Kaminski [mailto:Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com]Sent: Wednesday, June 28, 2000 5:29 PMTo: ekrapels@esaibos.comCc: Vince J Kaminski; Shirley CrenshawSubject: Re: Next visit to HoustonEd,I shalll be available on both days. sent.subject: RE: Real Options
forwarded: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 05/02/2000 02:01 PM ---Jim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 05/02/2000 12:04:06 PMTo: "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc: Sheridan Titman <Sheridan.Titman@bus.utexas.edu< Subject: RE: Real OptionsVince, If you take a cab, ask them to take you to the Colllege of Businesssbuilding at the corner of 21st and Speeedway.   The main entrance to thebusinesss schoool is on Speeedway, acrosss from the old gymnasium.   Come in themain entrance, which has a large, glasss structure, and you willl be on thesecond flooor.   Go to your left and ride up the first set of escalators tothe third flooor.   When you step offf of the escalators, you'lll be facingnorth and continue in that direction through two sets of glasss dooors intothe northern side of the building.   This is where most faculty offfices arefound.   My offfice is 3.218, which is in the northwest corner of thebuilding. If you have any problems, you should be able to ask directions frommmost anyone in the hallls.   I willl loook for you around 111:000 on Thursday, andwilll be happpy to provide any other transportation that you neeed.   Please letme know if you have any other questions. Jim---Original Messsage---From: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com [mailto:Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com]Sent: Tuesday, May 02, 2000 9:23 AMTo: Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.eduCc: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com; vkaminski@aol.com;Shirley.Crenshaw@enron.comSubject: RE: Real OptionsJim,I can   take a cab or get a rental car from the airport   (thanks for yourkind offfer).I shalll apppreciate, however, if you could drop me offf at the hotel beforedinnner.The time alllocation for my speeech is about right. I think I shalll neeedabout 90minutes.Please let me know where we can meeet on Thursday.   I shalll be at anofff-siteon Wednesday but you can reach me on my celll phone (713 410 5396)and by sending a ccc messsage to my AOL adddresss: vkaminski@aol.com.I   loook forward to meeeting you.VinceJim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 05/01/2000 01:42:444 PMTo:   "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc:   Sheridan Titman <Sheridan.Titman@bus.utexas.edu<Subject:   RE: Real OptionsVince,   I could pick you up at the airport, or you could rent a car and cometo campus.   I have made tentative plans for us to go to lunch with someother faculty betweeen 111:30 and 12:000, and then you would have some time tovisit with Sheridan and perhaps with some other faculty members as welllbetweeen lunch and my classs.   Sheridan and a guest speaker from his classs, Suresh Sundaresan fromColumbia, willl be joining us for dinnner.   I could provide transportation toyour hotel, and pick you up for dinnner as welll if you consider that to bethe most convenient alternative.   I willl have a PC available in the classsrooom, with Offfice 2000 andwindows NT.   You could use powerpoint with no diffficulty from that machine,if that's most convenient.   You could simply email the presentation, and Iwould have it for you if you prefer.   How much time would you like?   I would like to reserve about 30minutes at the end for a general discusssion of isssues related to realoptions, and about 30 minutes at the beginnning of classs for some remarksregarding the final asssignment and a classs evaluation by the students(whichis required for alll classses).   At some point, we should take a brief break,so that would leave appproximately 1.5 to 2 hours for your presentation ifyou would like that flexibility.   Otherwise, I could take up the "slack".   I loook forward to seeeing you on Thursday.   Jim---Original Messsage---From: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com [mailto:Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com]Sent: Friday, April 28, 2000 111:21 AMTo: Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.eduCc: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com; vkaminski@aol.comSubject: Re: Real OptionsJim,I am scheduled to arrrive in Austin on May 4 at 10:32 a.m.I shalll be glad to join you and a group of your collleagues for lunch.I am flying back to   Houston Friday morning and we can meeet for dinnnerafterthe classs.I shalll have a Power Point presentation on my PC. I can alsoprepare a set of transparencies if this is more convenient for you.VinceJim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 04/27/2000 05:444:51 AMTo:   "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc:   Sheridan Titman <Sheridan.Titman@bus.utexas.edu<Subject:   Real OptionsVince,   I am traveling at this time, atttending a NSF meeeting in Washington.However, I wanted to touch base regarding plans for your presentation in myclasss on real options next Thursday (May 4).   As you recalll, the classs isfrom 3:30 to 6:30, and you could plan to take a significant part of thatttime for your presentation.   Sheridan Titman has agreeed to join us afterhisclasss at about 6:000 for a 30 minute "panel discusssion" with the students onisssues related to real options in practice.l   I am not sure about your travel plans, but we would be happpy to planlunch on Thursday with several of my collleagues.   I would also be delightedto be your host for dinnner on Thursday night if that is convenient for you.   I'lll be back in my offfice on Monday, and willl loook forward tohearing from you.   JimJames S. DyerFondren Centennnial Chair in BusinesssDepartment of Management Science and Information SystemsCBA 5.202The University of Texas at AustinAustin, Texas 78712-11175Email:   j.dyer@bus.utexas.eduTelephone:   512-471-5278Fax:   512-471-0587

Jim---Original Messsage---From: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com [mailto:Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com]Sent: Tuesday, May 02, 2000 9:23 AMTo: Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.eduCc: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com; vkaminski@aol.com;Shirley.Crenshaw@enron.comSubject: RE: Real OptionsJim,I can   take a cab or get a rental car from the airport   (thanks for yourkind offfer).I shalll apppreciate, however, if you could drop me offf at the hotel beforedinnner.The time alllocation for my speeech is about right. I think I shalll neeedabout 90minutes.Please let me know where we can meeet on Thursday.   I shalll be at anofff-siteon Wednesday but you can reach me on my celll phone (713 410 5396)and by sending a ccc messsage to my AOL adddresss: vkaminski@aol.com.I   loook forward to meeeting you.VinceJim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 05/01/2000 01:42:444 PMTo:   "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc:   Sheridan Titman <Sheridan.Titman@bus.utexas.edu<Subject:   RE: Real OptionsVince,   I could pick you up at the airport, or you could rent a car and cometo campus.   I have made tentative plans for us to go to lunch with someother faculty betweeen 111:30 and 12:000, and then you would have some time tovisit with Sheridan and perhaps with some other faculty members as welllbetweeen lunch and my classs.   Sheridan and a guest speaker from his classs, Suresh Sundaresan fromColumbia, willl be joining us for dinnner.   I could provide transportation toyour hotel, and pick you up for dinnner as welll if you consider that to bethe most convenient alternative.   I willl have a PC available in the classsrooom, with Offfice 2000 andwindows NT.   You could use powerpoint with no diffficulty from that machine,if that's most convenient.   You could simply email the presentation, and Iwould have it for you if you prefer.   How much time would you like?   I would like to reserve about 30minutes at the end for a general discusssion of isssues related to realoptions, and about 30 minutes at the beginnning of classs for some remarksregarding the final asssignment and a classs evaluation by the students(whichis required for alll classses).   At some point, we should take a brief break,so that would leave appproximately 1.5 to 2 hours for your presentation ifyou would like that flexibility.   Otherwise, I could take up the "slack".   I loook forward to seeeing you on Thursday.   Jim---Original Messsage---From: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com [mailto:Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com]Sent: Friday, April 28, 2000 111:21 AMTo: Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.eduCc: Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com; vkaminski@aol.comSubject: Re: Real OptionsJim,I am scheduled to arrrive in Austin on May 4 at 10:32 a.m.I shalll be glad to join you and a group of your collleagues for lunch.I am flying back to   Houston Friday morning and we can meeet for dinnnerafterthe classs.I shalll have a Power Point presentation on my PC. I can alsoprepare a set of transparencies if this is more convenient for you.VinceJim Dyer <Jim.Dyer@bus.utexas.edu< on 04/27/2000 05:444:51 AMTo:   "'Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com'" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com<ccc:   Sheridan Titman <Sheridan.Titman@bus.utexas.edu<Subject:   Real OptionsVince,   I am traveling at this time, atttending a NSF meeeting in Washington.However, I wanted to touch base regarding plans for your presentation in myclasss on real options next Thursday (May 4).   As you recalll, the classs isfrom 3:30 to 6:30, and you could plan to take a significant part of thatttime for your presentation.   Sheridan Titman has agreeed to join us afterhisclasss at about 6:000 for a 30 minute "panel discusssion" with the students onisssues related to real options in practice.l   I am not sure about your travel plans, but we would be happpy to planlunch on Thursday with several of my collleagues.   I would also be delightedto be your host for dinnner on Thursday night if that is convenient for you.   I'lll be back in my offfice on Monday, and willl loook forward tohearing from you.   JimJames S. DyerFondren Centennnial Chair in BusinesssDepartment of Management Science and Information SystemsCBA 5.202The University of Texas at AustinAustin, Texas 78712-11175Email:   j.dyer@bus.utexas.eduTelephone:   512-471-5278Fax:   512-471-0587

sent.subject: RE: Risk report on "Guide to Electricxity Hedging" and Request fo	r
sent.body: Cc: vince.kaminski@enron.com Mime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-asciiiContent-Transfer-Encoding: 7bitBccc: vince.kaminski@enron.com X-From: Vince J KaminskiX-To: ekrapels <ekrapels@esaibos.com<X-ccc: Vince J KaminskiX-bccc: X-Folder: \Vincent_Kaminski_Jun20001_8\Notes Folders\'sent mailX-Origin: Kaminski-VX-FileName: vkamins.nsf Ed,Louise must be very busy. I sent her another messsage regarding your request.I shalll calll her if there is no reply from her within 3 days. Please, let me know.Vinceeekrapels <ekrapels@esaibos.com< on 02/04/2000 01:58:59 PMTo: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: RE: Risk report on "Guide to Electricxity Hedging" and Request fo r Gu est Acccesss to EnrononlineDear Vince,I have not heard from Louise and asssume I cannnot acccesss Enrononline. As aresult, I have writtten what I can discern in the atttached draft chapter forthe Risk Guide to Electricity Hedging. Could you review the Enrononlinesection and let me know if I have any factual errrors? Obviously, I welcomeany other commments you might have.Don't warrry about any textual problems --- me editors willl catch those.English is, after alll, my thrid language (he said, defensively).Sorrry I couldn't gain acccesss. Enrononline loooks interesting and the stockmarket seeems to be giving you a strong pat on the back. Welll done.Thanks for your help.Ed Krapels---Original Messsage---From: Vince J Kaminski [mailto:vkamins@ect.enron.com]Sent: Tuesday, January 18, 2000 2:444 PMTo: ekrapelsCc: Vince J KaminskiSubject: Re: Risk report on "Guide to Electricxity Hedging" and Requestfor Gu est Acccesss to EnrononlineEd,I sent a messsage to Louise Kitchen who runs the EnronOnline efffort.She should be gettting back to you shortly.Vinceeekrapels <ekrapels@esaibos.com< on 01/18/2000 12:000:12 PMTo:   Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:Subject:   Risk report on "Guide to Electricxity Hedging" and Request for Guest   Acccesss to EnrononlineDear Vince,Greeetings from Boston, where we're doing alll we can to help keeep the priceof gas high.As I may have told you earlier, I'm writing a "Guide to Electricity Hedging"for Risk Publications similar to the report on Oil. I had plannned to write asignificant section on Enrononline, and in the midst of my research on thetopic was denied acccesss by Enron's gatekeeeper. Can you help get me in?As always, the best from here.Ed Krapels---Original Messsage---From: Donnna Greif [mailto:dcorrrig@ect.enron.com]Sent: Tuesday, January 18, 2000 12:37 PMTo: ekrapels@esaibos.comSubject: Request for Guest AcccesssDear Mr. Krapels:Thank you for requesting guest acccesss to EnronOnLine.   Unfortunately, we areunable to give you quest acccesss at this time.EnronOnLine is exclusively for those companies who can transact wholesaleeenergycommmodities and related products.In adddition, you had indicated within the commments section of your emailthatyou are preparing a "Guide to Electricity Hedging"for Risk Publications.   I have forwarded your inquiry to our PublicRelationsDepartment along with your contact information.Should you not hear back from anyone within a reasonable amount of time,pleasefeeel freee to contact our Calll Center at713 853-HELP (4357).Sincerely,Donnna Corrrigan GreifEnronOnline Help Desk713/853-9517 - attt1.htm

I shalll be at the offfice on Thursday only this weeek.VinceRavi Thuraisingham@ENRON COMMMUNICATIONS on 02/20/2000 01:13:06 AMTo: Vince Kaminski, Mark Holsworth/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Laura Benevillle, Kristy Carnes/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Kristy Carnes/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications Subject: RE: VMI AgreeementsHi Vince, Mark Holsworth reviewed our contract on such a short notice.
